revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1914 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Army Black Knights|Army Cadets]] '''Professional championships''' * [[Ohio League|Ohio League champions]] – [[Akron Pros|Akron Parratt's Indians]] '''Events''' * 15 November — [[Harry Turner (American football)|Harry Turner]], of the [[Canton Bulldogs|Canton Professionals]], becomes the first player to die from game-related injuries in the "Ohio League", the direct predecessor to the [[National Football League]].
==[[Association football]]== '''Brazil''' * Formation of the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]] (Confederação Brasileira de Futebol or CBF) * [[Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras]] officially founded in [[São Paulo]] on August 26.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} '''England''' * [[1913–14 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Blackburn Rovers]] 51 points, [[Aston Villa]] 44, [[Middlesbrough FC|Middlesbrough]] 43, [[Oldham Athletic]] 43, [[West Bromwich Albion]] 43, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 42 * [[1914 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Burnley FC|Burnley]] 1–0 [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[SpVgg Fürth]] (2–2) 3–2 [[VfB Leipzig]] at Magdeburg '''Portugal''' * Formation in [[Lisbon]] of the [[Portuguese Football Federation]] (Federação Portuguesa de Futebol or FPF) '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] * [[1914 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] 4–1 [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]] (replay following 0–0 draw)
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1914 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * 26 September – [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] wins the 18th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 6.9 (45) to 4.15 (39) in the [[1914 VFL Grand Final]] '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 19 September – [[Port Adelaide Magpies|Port Adelaide]] 13.15 (93) defeats [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 1.8 (14) for their second successive SAFL flag and eighth overall * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Jack Ashley (footballer)|Jack Ashley]] (Port Adelaide) '''[[West Australian Football League]]''' * 10 October – [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 5.13 (43) defeats [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 3.6 (24) for its ninth WAFL premiership. '''Events''' * [[Melbourne University Football Club|University]] withdraws from the VFL at the end of the season * Port Adelaide become the only SAFA/SAFL/SANFL team to finish with a [[perfect season]], overall winning thirty consecutive matches including one against a combined team from the other six SAFL clubs and one against Carlton.<ref>Devaney, John; [http://australianfootball.com/articles/view/The%2BInvincibles%2Bat%2Bplay%2B-%2BSAFL%2BRnd%2B8%2B1914%253A%2BPort%2BAdelaide%2Bv%2BSouths/16 ‘The Invincibles at Play’]</ref>
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[AIK Bandy|AIK]] 4–2 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 9–13 October — [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] (NL) defeats [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]] (AL) to win the [[1914 World Series]] by 4 games to 0 '''Events''' * The "Federal League War" ensues when the Federal League leaves [[Minor League Baseball]] and competes with the two established major leagues. Retaining clubs in Kansas City, Indianapolis, St Louis, Chicago and Pittsburgh, the Federal League sets up additional clubs in Buffalo, Baltimore and Brooklyn. * [[Baltimore Terrapins]] are a great popular success and drive the minor [[Baltimore Orioles (minor league)|Orioles]] out of business, so creating the basis of the baseball anti–trust case * 22 April — [[Babe Ruth]] pitches his first professional game for the [[Baltimore Orioles (minor league)|Baltimore Orioles]] at age 19
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] spends the year moving from one country to another but stages exhibition fights as far afield as [[Gothenburg]] and [[Buenos Aires]]. In June, he defends his world heavyweight title against [[Frank Moran]] in Paris and wins over 20 rounds. * 1 to 24 January — Danish boxer Waldemar Holberg defeats Ray Bronson over 20 rounds in [[Melbourne]] and claims the vacant [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship. Just 23 days later, Holberg loses the title to Tom McCormick after a sixth round foul, also at Melbourne. * 21 March — McCormick loses the welterweight title to [[Matt Wells (boxer)|Matt Wells]] over 20 rounds at [[Sydney]]. * 30 March — a [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship (108 lb to 112 lb) is proposed for the first time after [[Jimmy Wilde]] defeats Eugene Husson in London. Wilde, subsequently ranked by most experts as the greatest-ever flyweight, holds the title until 1923. * 7 April — [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] defeats [[George Chip]] with a surprise first round knockout in [[Brooklyn]], New York, to take the [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship. McCoy holds the title until 1917. * With a series of wins from April to November, [[Jack Dillon]] resolves the long-standing issue of the vacant [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship in his favour. He defeats [[Battling Levinsky]], [[Bob Moha]], Frank Mantell and Charley Weinert to claim the title, which he holds until 1916. * 3 June — [[Kid Williams]] defeats [[Johnny Coulon]] by a third round knockout at Vernon, California, to win the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship. Williams holds the title until 1917. * 7 July — [[Freddie Welsh]] defeats [[Willie Ritchie]] over 20 rounds in London to win the [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship. Welsh holds the title until 1917. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [[Jack Dillon]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[George Chip]] → [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant → Waldemar Holberg → Tom McCormick → [[Matt Wells (boxer)|Matt Wells]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Willie Ritchie]] → [[Freddie Welsh]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Coulon]] → [[Kid Williams]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[6th Grey Cup]] – [[Toronto Argonauts]] 14–2 [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[1914 English cricket season]] is cancelled at the end of August because of the outbreak of the [[First World War]]. The last four matches to be played all finish on 2 September and the remaining five scheduled fixtures are cancelled. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Surrey CCC|Surrey]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – ''undecided'' * Most runs – [[Jack Hobbs]] 2697 @ 58.63 (HS 226) * Most wickets – [[Colin Blythe]] 170 @ 15.19 (BB 9–97) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Johnny Douglas]], [[Percy Fender]], [[Wally Hardinge]], [[Donald Knight (cricketer)|Donald Knight]], [[Sydney Smith (cricketer)|Sydney Smith]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Charlie Macartney]] 892 @ 111.50 (HS 201) * Most wickets – [[Charles Kelleway]] 45 @ 12.68 (BB 7–35) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] shared with [[Muslims cricket team|Muslims]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Philippe Thys]] (Belgium) wins the 12th [[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – Gosta Sandahl (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – Opika von Méray Horváth (Hungary) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Ludowika Jakobsson-Eilers / Walter Jakobsson (Finland)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1914 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Harry Vardon]] * [[1914 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – J L C Jenkins * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Francis Ouimet]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1914 Grand National|Grand National]] – Sunloch * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Princess Dorrie]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Kennymore]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Durbar (horse)|Durbar]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Princess Dorrie * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Black Jester]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Kingsburgh '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Beehive '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Civil War * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Land of Song '''USA''' * [[1914 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Old Rosebud * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Holiday * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Luke McLuke]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Toronto Blueshirts]] wins the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) championship and their first [[Stanley Cup]]. '''Events''' * [[Victoria Aristocrats]] wins the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] (PCHA) championship * Blueshirts play Aristocrats in a challenge series with Blueshirts winning by three games to nil. The NHA and PCHA agree to start an annual playoff in 1915 to decide the Stanley Cup winner. * Regina Victorias wins the [[1914 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1914 in motorsport}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 71st [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''International''' *[[1914 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand]] '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Salford Red Devils|Salford]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Hull F.C.]] 6–0 [[Wakefield Trinity]] at [[Thrum Hall]], [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] 5–0 [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] 19–3 [[Bradford Bulls|Bradford Northern]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (outright winner) '''New Zealand''' *[[1914 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 32nd [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1915 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Oscar Mathisen]] (Norway)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Arthur O'Hara Wood]] (Australia) defeats [[Gerald Patterson]] (Australia) 6–4 6–3 5–7 6–1 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Norman Brookes]] (Australia) defeats [[Anthony Wilding]] (New Zealand) 6–4 6–4 7–5 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] defeats [[Ethel Thomson Larcombe]] 7–5 6–4 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Max Decugis]] defeats [[Jean Samazeuilh]] 3–6 6–1 6–4 6–4 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Marguerite Broquedis]] defeats [[Suzanne Lenglen]] 5–7 6–4 6–3 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Norris Williams]] defeats [[Maurice McLoughlin]] 6–3 8–6 10–8 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Mary Browne]] defeats [[Marie Wagner]] 6–2 1–6 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1914 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|Australasia}} 3–2 {{davis|USA|1912}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) [[New York City]], [[United States]]
==[[Yacht racing]]== * [[1914 America's Cup]] – ''[[Resolute (yacht)|Resolute]]'' competes against the ''[[Vanitie]]'' but the race is cancelled due to the onset of [[World War I]].<ref name=hustle>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Resolute Beats All Cup Course Records. Shamrock Will Have to Hustle to Better Yesterday's Time. 30 Miles in 3:16:41 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1914/06/11/archives/resolute-beats-all-cup-course-records-shamrock-will-have-to-hustle.html |quote=The flag officers' sloop Resolute covered herself with much seafoam and more glory in her first race over the America's Cup course off Sandy Hook yesterday. She not only left her chief rival, Vanitie, far astern, but set such a hot pace in the fifteen-mile thrash to windward and back that she broke all previous records for the thirty-mile cup course. ... Selah B. Howell, her professional sailing master, Resolute's rig consisted of mainsail, and single headsail, and each canvas fitted smooth as a glove. ... |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 11, 1914 |accessdate=2010-10-15 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''[[1975–76 NHL season|1975–76]] [[California Golden Seals]] season''' would be the Seals' ninth and final [[season (sports)|season]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] of California. The Seals were led by rookie [[Dennis Maruk]].
Maruk centered the 3M line with [[Bob Murdoch (ice hockey, born 1954)|Bob Murdoch]] and [[Al MacAdam]]. Both Maruk and MacAdam scored over 30 goals while Murdoch led the team in power play goals. Although they recorded a solid improvement over the previous season, the Seals fell 7 points shy of a playoff spot.
Owner Mel Swig was counting on the construction of a new arena in San Francisco, but after the proposal was defeated, he was convinced by minority owner [[George Gund III]] to relocate the franchise to Cleveland, where it was renamed [[Cleveland Barons (NHL)|Cleveland Barons]].<ref>http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nhl/caloak/seals</ref>

revision.text:
{{NHLTeamSeason |League=NHL |Season=1984–85 |year=1984 |Team=Calgary Flames |Conference=[[Western Conference (NHL)|Campbell]] |ConferenceRank= |Division=[[Smythe Division|Smythe]] |DivisionRank=3rd |Record=41–27–12 |HomeRecord=23–11–6 |RoadRecord=18–16–6 |GoalsFor=363 (2nd) |GoalsAgainst=302 (10th) |GeneralManager=[[Cliff Fletcher]] |Coach=[[Bob Johnson (ice hockey, born 1931)|Bob Johnson]] |Captain=[[Lanny McDonald]]
[[Jim Peplinski]] and
[[Doug Risebrough]] |AltCaptain= None |Arena=[[Pengrowth Saddledome|Olympic Saddledome]] |Attendance=16,683 |GoalsLeader=[[Kent Nilsson]] (37)
[[Håkan Loob|Hakan Loob]] (37) |AssistsLeader=Kent Nilsson (62) |PointsLeader= Kent Nilsson (99) |PIMLeader=[[Tim Hunter (ice hockey)|Tim Hunter]] (259) |WinsLeader= [[Réjean Lemelin|Rejean Lemelin]] (30) |GAALeader= Rejean Lemelin (3.46) }} The '''[[1984–85 NHL season|1984–85]] [[Calgary Flames]] season''' was the [[Calgary Flames seasons|fifth]] [[Season (sports)|season]] in [[Calgary]] and 13th for the Flames franchise in the [[National Hockey League]]. It was a breakout season for the Flames, as they tied a franchise record for wins with 41, and set new team marks for points, 95, and goals for, 363. Despite the improvement, the Flames managed only a third-place finish in the [[Smythe Division]].Year-by-year results, ''2007–08 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', p. 105. In the playoffs, the Flames met the second place [[Winnipeg Jets (1972–96)|Winnipeg Jets]], where they fell three games to one. Following the playoff disappointment, General Manager [[Cliff Fletcher]] began a series of moves to remake the team that included shipping out top scorer [[Kent Nilsson]] in a deal for a pair of second round draft picks that would eventually become [[Joe Nieuwendyk]] and [[Stéphane Matteau|Stephane Matteau]].[http://www.legendsofhockey.net/LegendsOfHockey/jsp/SearchPlayer.jsp?player=13853 Kent Nilsson profile] @ ''legendsofhockey.net Calgary hosted the [[37th National Hockey League All-Star Game|1985 All-Star Game]] at the [[Pengrowth Saddledome|Olympic Saddledome]], a 6–4 victory by the [[Wales Conference]] over the [[Campbell Conference]]. The Flames were represented at the game by [[Al MacInnis]] and [[Paul Reinhart]].All-Star selections, ''2007–08 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', p. 22. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Regular season== ===Season standings=== {{1984–85 NHL Smythe Division standings |team=CAL}} ==Schedule and results== {| class="toccolours" width=90% style="clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! revision.text:
'''{{lang|it|Art.52, Norme organizzative interne della FIGC}}''' ("Article 52 of the [[Italian Football Federation]] regulations for internal organisation") governs the status of [[Phoenix club (sports)|phoenix club]]s in [[football in Italy]]. The article was changed in 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/Assets/contentresources_2/ContenutoGenerico/31.$plit/C_2_ContenutoGenerico_4792_lstAllegati_Allegato0_upfAllegato.pdf|title=Comunicato Ufficiale (C.U.) N°175/A (2003–04)|date=14 May 2004|accessdate=11 July 2015|first=Franco|last=Carraro|work=Consiglio Federale|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian}}</ref> 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/Assets/contentresources_2/ContenutoGenerico/65.$plit/C_2_ContenutoGenerico_18693_StrilloComunicatoUfficiale_lstAllegati_Allegato_0_upfAllegato.pdf|title=C.U. N°98/A (2007–08)|date=5 May 2008|accessdate=11 July 2015|first=Giancarlo|last=Abete|work=Consiglio Federale|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian}}</ref> 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/Assets/contentresources_2/ContenutoGenerico/83.$plit/C_2_ContenutoGenerico_25073_StrilloComunicatoUfficiale_lstAllegati_Allegato_0_upfAllegato.pdf|title=C.U. N°130/A (2009–10)|date=8 June 2010|accessdate=11 July 2015|first=Giancarlo|last=Abete|work=Consiglio Federale|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian}}</ref> and 2014.
==Comma 3== According to Comma 3 of the article, a new company from the same city could be admitted to the same division to replace a bankrupted football club, if the company had acquired the bankrupted company as well as willing to take the liabilities to pay sports related debt, as well as taxes.

==Comma 6 to 7 (Lodo Petrucci)== Lodo Petrucci was a ruling name after [[Gianni Petrucci]]. Ratified in 2004, instead of acquiring the sports title by clearing the debt, FIGC could awarded the title to a new company based on sports merit of the old club. However, the club automatically relegated one level below the original club. In 2008 the rule had changed to two levels below the original club, and limited to Serie A and B clubs only. The ruling was abolished in 2015.

==Comma 10== Comma 10 of the article allowed a new company could be admit to Serie D to replace the old football club that not admitted to professional leagues. It was the Comma 9 but became 10 in the 2010 amendment. One of the example was the failed auction of [[Parma F.C.]], which the debt was stood at €22.6 million.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/22/parma-relegated-serie-d-fail-new-owner | title=Parma relegated to Serie D after failing to find a new owner | work=[[The Guardian]] | publisher=Guardian News and Media | accessdate=22 June 2015 | location=London | first=Ian | last=McCourt | date=22 June 2015}}</ref> (reduced from over €70 million by the resettlement during administration<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Parma/19-03-2015/parma-si-decide-futuro-societa-oggi-udienza-prefallimentare-110161338416.shtml|title= Il Parma è ufficialmente fallito. Ma domenica col Torino si gioca |date=19 March 2015|work=La Gazzetta dello Sport|language=Italian}}</ref>)

revision.text:
{{National rugby union | unionname = Brazilian Rugby Confederation | nativename = Confederação Brasileira de Rugby | logo = | logosize = 150px | founded = 1972 | IRB = 1995 | region = [[Confederación Sudamericana de Rugby|CONSUR]] | regionyear = 1997 | president = Sami Arap | coach = [[Rodolfo Ambrosio]] | womenscoach = João Nogueira | countryflag = Brazil | url = [http://www.brasilrugby.com.br/ Confederação Brasileira de Rugby] }} The '''Brazilian Rugby Confederation''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: ''Confederação Brasileira de Rugby'', '''CBRu''') is the governing body for [[rugby union]] in [[Brazil]]. It was founded in 1972 and became affiliated to the [[International Rugby Board]] in 1995.
The confederation has six affiliate state federations: Gaúcha (Rio Grande do Sul), Catarinense (Santa Catarina), Paranaense (Paraná), Paulista (São Paulo), Mineira (Minas Gerais), and Fluminense (Rio de Janeiro). Other state federations are unaffiliated with the CBRu.
It organizes the [[Campeonato Brasileiro de Rugby]] (Série A / Super 8), Taça Tupi (Série B) and Campeonato Brasileiro de Rugby Sevens.
From 2010 onwards, the Brazilian Rugby Union has been sponsored by [[Topper (sports)|Topper]] and [[Bradesco]]
==See also== * [[Brazil national rugby union team]] * [[Rugby union in Brazil]]
==External links== *{{Pt icon}} [http://www.brasilrugby.com.br/ Associação Brasileira de Rugby] - Official Site

revision.text:
The '''Chess World Cup 2005''' served as a qualification tournament for the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2007]]. It was held as a 128-player tournament, between 27 November and 17 December 2005, in [[Khanty-Mansiysk]], Russia.
Top ten players qualified for the candidates matches of the World Chess Championship 2007. One of them ([[Étienne Bacrot]]) has qualified for the candidates matches via rating, freeing the place for the eleventh player at the World Cup ([[Vladimir Malakhov (chess player)|Vladimir Malakhov]]).
The World Cup was won by [[Levon Aronian]].
==Background== The 2005 World Cup was part of the cycle for the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2007]]. Three of the players at the World Cup, [[Levon Aronian]], [[Alexander Grischuk]] and [[Boris Gelfand]], went on to qualify for the World Championship, which was held as an eight-player double round-robin event, with Gelfand finishing third.
Four top finishers of the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2005]] ([[Veselin Topalov]], [[Viswanathan Anand]], [[Peter Svidler]] and [[Alexander Morozevich]]) were already invited to the World Championship 2007 and thus exempt from the World Cup.
==Playing conditions== The tournament was in the style of the FIDE World Chess Championships between 1998 and 2004: each round consisted of a two-game match, followed by tie breaks at faster time controls if required. In rounds 1–3 losing players were eliminated. However, in rounds 4–6 defeated players progressed to the next round, to determine standings of the 16 best players.
The time control for regular games was 90 minutes for the first 40 moves and 15 minutes for the rest of the game, with 30 seconds added after each move. Tie breaks consisted of two rapid chess games (25 minutes each + 10 seconds per move); followed by two blitz games if required (5 minutes + 10 seconds per move); followed by a single [[Armageddon chess]] game if required (white has 6 minutes and must win, black has 5 minutes and only needs to draw).
==Qualification== The following players qualified for the World Cup: *Three of the four semi-finalists of the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2004]] ([[Rustam Kasimdzhanov]], [[Michael Adams (chess player)|Michael Adams]] and [[Teimour Radjabov]]); the fourth semi-finalist, [[Veselin Topalov]], was the reigning FIDE World Champion and already had a berth in the next championship. *[[Women's World Chess Championship|Women's World Champion]] 2004 ([[Antoaneta Stefanova]]). *[[World Junior Chess Championship|Junior World Champion]] 2004 ([[Pendyala Harikrishna]]). *22 players with the highest [[Elo rating]]. The average ratings from July 2004 and January 2005 were used. *90 players qualified from the continental and zonal championships: **46 players from Europe, **19 players from the Americas, **19 players from Asia and Oceania, **6 players from Africa. *8 nominees of the FIDE President. *3 nominees of the local Organising Committee.

{{use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = CHI | NOCname = [[Chilean Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1952 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.coch.cl }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Helsinki]] | competitors = 59 (55 men and 4 women) | sports = 9 | flagbearer = [[Adriana Millard]] | rank = 31 | gold = 0 | silver = 2 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Chile]]''' competed at the '''[[1952 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]]. 59 competitors, 55 men and 4 women, took part in 33 events in 9 sports.{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/CHI/summer/1952/ |title=Chile at the 1952 Helsinki Summer Games |accessdate=22 February 2015 |work=sports-reference.com}} ==Medalists== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Medal !Name !Sport !Event |- | {{silver medal}} || {{sortname|Oscar|Cristi}} || [[Equestrian at the 1952 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] || Jumping Individual Competition |- | {{silver medal}} || {{sortname|Ricardo|Echeverria}}
[[Oscar Cristi]]
[[César Mendoza]] || [[Equestrian at the 1952 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] || Jumping Team Competition |} ==Athletics== {{main|Athletics at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ==Basketball== {{main|Basketball at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ===Men's Team Competition=== *'''Main Round (Group D)''' ** Defeated Cuba (53-52) ** Defeated Egypt (74-46) ** Lost to France (43-52) *'''Final Round (Group B)''' ** Lost to Brazil (44-75) ** Lost to United States (55-103) ** Lost to Soviet Union (60-78) *'''Classification Matches''' ** '''5th/8th place''': Defeated Bulgaria (60-53) ** '''5th/6th place''': Defeated Brazil (58-49) → '''Fifth place''' *'''Team Roster''' **[[Pedro Araya Zabala]] **[[Rufino Bernedo Zorzano]] **[[Eduardo Cordero Fernández]] **[[Hugo Fernández Diez]] **[[Exequiel Figueroa Reyes]] **[[Juan Gallo Chinchilla]] **[[Erich Mahn Godoy]] **[[Victor Mahana Badrie]] **[[Juan Ostoic Ostoic]] **[[Hernán Ramos Muñoz]] **[[Alvaro Salvadores Salvi]] **[[Hernán Raffo Abarca]] **[[Orlando Silva Infante]] ==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ===Road Competition=== '''Men's Individual Road Race (190.4 km)''' *[[Hernán Masanés]] — did not finish (→ no ranking) *[[Héctor Droguett]] — did not finish (→ no ranking) *[[Héctor Mellado]] — did not finish (→ no ranking) *[[Hugo Miranda (cyclist)|Hugo Miranda]] — did not finish (→ no ranking) ===Track Competition=== '''Men's 1.000m Time Trial''' *[[Hernán Masanés]] ** Final — 1:15.9 (→ 17th place) '''Men's 1.000m Sprint Scratch Race''' *[[Hernán Masanés]] — 14th place ==Equestrian== {{main|Equestrian at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ==Football== {{main|Football at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ==Modern pentathlon== {{main|Modern pentathlon at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} Three male pentathletes represented Chile in 1952. ;Individual * [[Nilo Floody]] * [[Hernán Fuentes]] * [[Luis Carmona]] ;Team * Nilo Floody * Hernán Fuentes * Luis Carmona ==Rowing== {{main article|Rowing at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} Chile had one male rowers participate in one out of seven [[rowing (sport)|rowing]] events in 1952.{{cite Sports-Reference |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/CHI/summer/1952/ROW/ |title=Chile Rowing at the 1952 Helsinki Summer Games |accessdate= 10 March 2018}} ; [[Rowing at the 1952 Summer Olympics – Men's single sculls|Men's single sculls]] * [[Carlos Adueza]] ==Shooting== {{main|Shooting at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} Two shooters represented Chile in 1952. ;[[Shooting at the 1952 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre pistol|50 m pistol]] * [[Enrique Ojeda]] ;[[Shooting at the 1952 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre rifle three positions|50 m rifle, three positions]] * [[Juan Bizama]] ;[[Shooting at the 1952 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre rifle, prone|50 m rifle, prone]] * [[Juan Bizama]] ==Swimming== {{main|Swimming at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080522105330/http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] *[http://www.olympic.org/uk/athletes/results/search_r_uk.asp International Olympic Committee results database] {{Nations at the 1952 Summer Olympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1952 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Chile at the Summer Olympics by year|1952]] [[Category:1952 in Chilean sport|Olympics]] {{Chile-sport-stub}} {{1952-Olympic-stub}}

{{more footnotes|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | | stadium_name = Colonials Arena | nickname = | image = Island Sports Center (arena).svg | image_size = 150px | location = 7600 Grand Avenue
[[Neville Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | broke_ground = | opened = October, 1998 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Robert Morris University]] | operator = Robert Morris University | surface = 200' x 85' (hockey) | construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = RMU Island Sports Center Ice Arena
84 Lumber Arena | tenants = [[Pittsburgh Forge]] ([[North American Hockey League|NAHL]]) (2001–2003)
[[Robert Morris Colonials]] ([[NCAA]]) (2004–present) | seating_capacity = 1,200 (hockey) }} '''Colonials Arena''' (formerly '''The RMU Island Sports Center Ice Arena''' and later the '''84 Lumber Arena''') is a 1,200-seat [[ice hockey]] rink located at the '''RMU Island Sports Center''', accessible via exit 65 of [[Interstate 79]]{{cite web|last=Kitsko|first=Jeffrey|title=Pennsylvania Highways: Interstate 79 Exit Guide|url=http://www.pahighways.com/exits/I79exits.html|work=Pennsylvania Highways|accessdate=3 August 2012}} in the [[Pittsburgh]] suburb of [[Neville Island, Pennsylvania|Neville Island]] in [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny County]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]. The RMU Island Sports Center was built in 1998, and houses several ice and inline skating rinks, a golf range, a miniature golf course, athletic fields, a strength and fitness center, and a pro shop. Robert Morris University and 84 Lumber reached a deal by which 84 Lumber would receive naming rights as of March 21, 2012. The arena later dropped the 84 Lumber name before the 2017-18 season and reverted to being known as the Colonials Arena at the RMU Island Sports Center. It is home to the [[Robert Morris Colonials]] men's and women's [[NCAA Division I]] [[College ice hockey|ice hockey]] teams competing in [[Atlantic Hockey]] and [[College Hockey America]] respectively, as well as RMU's club hockey team competing at the [[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA Division I]] level in the [[College Hockey Mid-America]] conference (CHMA) and various local youth hockey programs. In addition, it is home to the [[Pittsburgh Curling Club]]. The arena served as the former home of the [[Pittsburgh Forge]] Junior-A [[NAHL]] team, which moved to [[Toledo, Ohio]] in 2003. ==Teams== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team !! League |- | [[Robert Morris Colonials men's ice hockey|Robert Morris Colonials]] || [[Atlantic Hockey]] ([[NCAA Division I]]) |- | [[Robert Morris Lady Colonials ice hockey|Robert Morris Lady Colonials]] || [[College Hockey America]] (NCAA Division I) |- | Robert Morris Colonials || [[College Hockey Mid-America]] ([[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]]) |- |} ==Gallery== File:IslandSportsCenter.jpg|A view of the Island Sports Center. File:IslandSportsCenter2.jpg|Another view of the Island Sports Center. File:HockeyatIslandSportsCenter.jpg|A youth [[ice hockey]] game at the Island Sports Center on September 26, 2010. File:TrackandFieldatIslandSportsCenter.jpg|The track and field at the Island Sports Center. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rmuislandsports.org RMU Island Sports Center website] {{Atlantic Hockey}} {{College Hockey America}} {{Pittsburgh Penguins}} {{CHMA}} {{Robert Morris Colonials men's ice hockey navbox}} {{Pittsburgh}} {{coord|40|31|7|N|80|9|0|W|display=t|type:landmark}} [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Penguins arenas]] [[Category:Robert Morris Colonials ice hockey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] {{Pennsylvania-sports-venue-stub}} {{Pittsburgh-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Deir ez-Zor Municipal Stadium
ملعب دير الزور البلدي | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = [[Deir ez-Zor]], [[Syria]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|33|38|N|35|44|41|E|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1960 | renovated = 1997, 2002 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Government of Syria | operator = General Sports Federation of Syria | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Al-Fotuwa SC|Al-Fotuwa]]
[[Al-Yaqdhah SC|Al-Yaqdhah]] | seating_capacity = 13,000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Deir ez-Zor Municipal Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|ملعب دير الزور البلدي}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Deir ez-Zor]], [[Syria]]. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches. The stadium has a capacity of 13,000 spectators.[http://www.alwehda.gov.sy/index.php/%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B2%D9%88%D8%B1/2062-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%A2%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%B8%D8%A9-%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B2%D9%88%D8%B1 Sports facilities in Deir ez-Zor] An artificial training field was opened near the stadium in 2007. However, the stadium was heavily damaged between 2015 and 2017, while being occupied by the militants of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == See also == *[[List of football stadiums in Syria]] [[Category:Football venues in Syria]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Syria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Deir ez-Zor]] {{syria-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Dnipro-Arena | nickname = | image = [[File:Dnipro-Arena4.jpg|250px|]] ---- | location = [[Dnipro]], [[Ukraine]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = April 1, 2005 | opened = September 14, 2008 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[PrivatBank]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = €40,000,000 | architect = [[Hochtief]] | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Dnipro]]
[[SC Dnipro-1]] | seating_capacity = 31,003 | dimensions = 105 m x 70 m }} The '''Dnipro-Arena''' ({{lang-uk|Дніпро-Арена}}) is a football [[stadium]] in [[Dnipro]], [[Ukraine]]. It is mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and hosts the homes matches of [[FC Dnipro]]. The stadium has a capacity of 31,003 people. It replaced Dnipro's old Soviet Metalurh Stadium. ==History== [[File:Dnipro Arena-View from Kucherevsky boulevard (North Enter).jpg|thumb|left|North entrance of the stadium]] The Dnipro-Arena staged the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - UEFA Group 6|2010 FIFA World Cup qualifying]] match between [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] and [[England national football team|England]] as the [[Olimpiysky National Sports Complex]] in [[Kiev]] was being rebuilt ready for [[UEFA Euro 2012]]. The Dnipro-Arena was chosen as a possible venue for [[UEFA Euro 2012]], but was dropped from the list in May 2009. The capacity fell short of the minimum 33,000 seats required by [[UEFA]].[https://www.theguardian.com/football/feedarticle/8499613 Kiev and Donetsk likely for Euro 2012, others uncertain][https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5it8f_MOzCKu2hxVHUUXwOvzetMIw UEFA names four Polish Euro 2012 host cities, one in Ukraine]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Dnipro-Arena hosted the 2009 [[Ukrainian Cup]] final, in which [[Vorskla Poltava]] beat [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] 1–0. Since the beginning of [[armed conflict|conflict]] in [[Eastern Ukraine]], Dnipro have played their European matches at the [[Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex|Olympic Stadium]] in [[Kiev]] at the behest of [[UEFA]], although there has been comparatively less conflict in Dnipro than other areas. ==See also== * [[PEOPLEnet Cup]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Dnipro Arena}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090811013249/http://www.fcdnipro.dp.ua/content/ru/?stadium Dnipro Arena on the official FC Dnipro site] * [http://www.stadiumguide.com/dniproarena/ Stadium Guide profile] {{Venues of Ukrainian PL}} {{FC Dnipro}} {{coord|48|27|37.2|N|35|1|56.9|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Dnipro]] [[Category:Football venues in Dnipropetrovsk Oblast]] [[Category:Sport in Dnipro]] [[Category:FC Dnipro]] [[Category:Sports venues in Dnipropetrovsk Oblast]] [[Category:SC Dnipro-1]] {{Ukraine-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{for|the WWII merchant ship|MV Empire Field}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Empire Field | image = [[File:Empire Field.jpg|300px]] | caption = [[BC Lions]] season opener against the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] on July 10, 2010 | location = [[Hastings Park]], [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | coordinates = {{coord|49|16|57.5|N|123|1|59.6|W|type:landmark_region:CA|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = March 2010 | opened = June 15, 2010 | demolished = November–December 2011 | owner = [[BC Pavilion Corporation]] | operator = [[Pacific National Exhibition]] | construction_cost = $14.4 million | general_contractor= [[Nussli Group]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | dimensions = | architect = | suites = 12 | tenants = [[BC Lions]] ([[Canadian Football League|CFL]]) (2010–2011)
[[Vancouver Whitecaps FC (MLS)|Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] ([[Major League Soccer|MLS]]) (2011) | seating_capacity = 27,528 | record_attendance = 27,528 }} '''Empire Field''' was a temporary [[Canadian football]] and [[soccer]] [[stadium]] built at [[Hastings Park]] in the Canadian city of [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. Located on the site of the former [[Empire Stadium (Vancouver)|Empire Stadium]], the 27,528 spectator venue was constructed to allow a new [[retractable roof]] to be installed at [[BC Place]] in 2010 and 2011. Empire Field was home to the [[Canadian Football League]]'s (CFL) [[BC Lions]] for the [[2010 BC Lions season|2010]] and part of the [[2011 BC Lions season|2011]] seasons, and for [[Major League Soccer]]'s (MLS) [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] for part of their debut [[2011 Vancouver Whitecaps FC season|2011 season]]. The venue was constructed by [[Nussli Group]] in three months, cost $14.4 million and opened on June 15, 2010. The venue featured 20,500 roofed bucket seats—with the remaining 7,000 being benches—12 [[luxury suite]]s, a press room, [[floodlights (sport)|flood lighting]] and a [[FieldTurf]] [[artificial turf]]. The venue's record attendance are two sell-out matches: for the Lions it occurred in inaugural 2010 regular-season match against the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]]; for the Whitecaps, it was a regular-season match against the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]]. Dismantling took place in November and December 2011 and the site is now used as a community playing field. ==History== Empire Field was built on the same lot as Empire Stadium, which was originally built for the [[1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]]. The 32,375-spectator stadium was used by the Lions from [[1954 BC Lions season|1954]] until [[1982 BC Lions season|1982]]. For soccer, the venue was used by [[North American Soccer League]]'s [[Vancouver Royals]] from 1967 to 1968 and subsequently by the [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1974–84)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] from [[1974 Vancouver Whitecaps season|1974]] to [[1982 Vancouver Whitecaps season|1982]]. Both the Lions and Whitecaps moved to the newly constructed, then 60,000 seat BC Place for the 1983 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2011/09/22/vancouver-will-remember-empire-field-fondly-finale-nears |title=Vancouver will remember Empire Field fondly as finale nears |last=MacMahon |first=Martin |date=September 22, 2011 |publisher=[[Major League Soccer]]}} Empire Stadium was demolished in 1993,{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/321002-empire-stadium-reborn-why-the-cfl-bog-will-insist-it-sucks |title=Empire Stadium Reborn: Why The CFL BOG Will Insist It Sucks |last=Writes |first=Tobi |date=January 6, 2010 |work=[[Bleacher Report]]}} and the location converted to a community sports park.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/sports/golf/With+temporary+stadium+Lions+Whitecaps+bank+nostalgia/2372224/story.html |title=With temporary stadium, Lions, Whitecaps bank on nostalgia |last=Little |first=Lyndon |date=December 22, 2009 |publisher=[[Canwest]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626080606/http://www.canada.com/sports/golf/With+temporary+stadium+Lions+Whitecaps+bank+nostalgia/2372224/story.html |archivedate=June 26, 2010}} The Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation opened Empire Bowl on the site on 2003, which consisted of a {{convert|5.5|ha}} lot, costing $2.9 million. It had irrigated grass soccer fields, two [[baseball diamond]]s and a gravel running track.{{cite news |url=http://www.vancourier.com/Vancouver+Empire+Field+reopening+slated+fall+2013/6548505/story.html |title=Vancouver’s Empire Field reopening slated for fall 2013 |work=[[The Vancouver Courier]] |first=Bob |last=Mackin |date=May 1, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=Elisfkc |fix-attempted=yes }} [[File:Empire Field near empty.jpg|thumb|left|The field in soccer configuration on April 2, 2011]] Following a 2007 roof deflation at BC Place, Premier [[Gordon Campbell]] announced on the plans to build a retractable roof on the stadium.{{cite news | url=https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=237961 |title=B.C. Place stadium to get retractable roof |work=[[The Sports Network]] |date=May 16, 2008 | accessdate=May 18, 2011}} Stadium owner and operator [[BC Pavilion Corporation]] (PavCo) announced on October 23, 2009 that they had signed a fix-cost agreement with PCL Constructors Canada to build a new roof, including the cost of a temporary stadium. The construction was financed through a loan from the provincial government to PavCo.{{cite news | url=http://www.vancouversun.com/sports/Place+million+upgrade/2137532/story.html |title=BC Place to get $458 million upgrade|work=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=May 16, 2008 | accessdate=May 18, 2011}} The decision to build the roof was, according to Whitecaps president [[Bob Lenarduzzi]], "key" to bringing a MLS franchise to Vancouver. In 2009, the Whitecaps signed a five-year agreement to play their home matches at BC Place, starting in 2011.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/08/25/bc-stadium-roof-delayed.html |title=BC Place retractable-roof project delayed |work=[[CBC News]] |date=August 25, 2009 | accessdate=May 18, 2011}} To allow the Lions to continue playing as normal and support the new Whitecaps franchise, PavCo decided to build the temporary venue at the [[Pacific National Exhibition]] (PNE) in [[Hastings Park]] in eastern Vancouver.{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/football/bc-place-to-be-gussied-up-in-time-for-2011-grey-cup/article1781720/ |title=B.C. Place to be gussied up in time for 2011 Grey Cup |last=Morris |first=Jim |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=August 25, 2009 | accessdate=May 18, 2011}} Because BC Place was to be used as the [[Olympic Stadium]] during the [[2010 Winter Olympics]], refurbishment could not start until after February 2010. The details for the stadium were launched av PNE and PavCo on December 22, 2009. The venue cost $14.4 million in a fixed-price contract, and was included in the $458 million set aside to renovate BC Place. Representatives from both teams stated that they hoped to play on the nostalgia factor for the affected seasons. The Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation stated immediately after the press release that they had not been consulted or informed about the decision to build a professional sports venue on their grounds. Although the board was responsible for operating the facilities, the land was owned by PNE, which is again owned by the city. There were no public hearings or a city council vote to decide on the issue. [[File:Empire under the moon.jpg|thumb|Whitecaps vs. [[Columbus Crew]] on July 6, 2011]] The contract to build the stadium was issued the Nussli Group of Switzerland, which specializes in the construction of temporary stadiums.{{cite web |url=http://www.journalofcommerce.com/article/id39401 |title=Overlay work wraps up Empire Field construction in Vancouver |last=Gilbert |first=Richard |date=June 23, 2010 |work=[[Journal of Commerce]]}} They used their NT grandstand system, which allowed for modular construction of stands. Construction implemented 2,500 tonnes of material. Nussli's senior project manager, Florian Weber, stated that the most difficult part of the construction was the occupancy permit, caused by the short construction schedule. Construction took 111 days,{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/1110/major-league-soccer/2011/03/28/2414565/business-off-the-pitch-temporary-stadiums-a-permanent |title=Is there a lower cost option for MLS clubs? |last=Savino |first=Christopher |date=May 28, 2011 |publisher=Goal.com}} and was completed in late June 2010. Several commentators stated that use of temporary stadiums on a permanent basis could be used for other MLS and CFL stadia. For instance, the price of building an 18,500 seat permanent [[soccer-specific stadium]] was averaging $200 million. After the reopening of BC Place, the stands at Empire Field were disassembled in November and December 2011, with the turf, locker rooms and lighting masts being left behind. Equipment and components leased from Nussli were returned.{{cite web|url=http://www.nussli.com/fileadmin/content/ueber_nussli/Downloads/Kundenmagazin/English/20101118_up__date_2010_en_low.pdf |title=A Real Novelty in North America |last=Kuhland |first=Karin |date=November 2010 |work=Update |publisher=[[Nussli Group]] |pages=3–4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714215409/http://www.nussli.com/fileadmin/content/ueber_nussli/Downloads/Kundenmagazin/English/20101118_up__date_2010_en_low.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2011 |df=mdy }} Public consultations regarding use of the lot were conducted until June 2012, after which it was decided to create a community sports park. It features a mountain bike park to the north, a {{convert|3.9|m|sp=us|adj=on}} wide [[running track]] around the field and a [[skateboarding]] and graffiti tunnel. The area around the turf was expanded, allowing for two east–west fields, rather than one north–south. The legacy items were valued at $2.8 million in 2010. ==Specifications== Empire Field was located in Hastings Park, in the Vancouver neighborhood of [[Hastings-Sunrise]], next to [[Playland (Vancouver)|Playland]], an [[amusement park]]. Other sports facilities at Hastings Park include [[Pacific Coliseum]] and [[PNE Agrodome|Agrodome]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pne.ca/aboutus/hastings-park-pne-master-plan.html |title=Hastings Park / PNE Master Plan |publisher=[[Pacific National Exhibition]]}} The venue was owned by the BC Pavilion Corporation, which in turn is owned by the provincial [[Government of British Columbia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nussli.us/projects/project-details/news/temporary-stadium-empire-field-vancouver-1160/402.html |title=Temporary Stadium, Empire Field Vancouver |publisher=[[Nussli Group]] |date=June 2010}} It lies on the grounds of and will be operated by the Pacific National Exhibition, which is owned by the [[Vancouver City Council]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pne.ca/aboutus/governance.html |title=Governance |publisher=[[Pacific National Exhibition]]}} [[File:Lions Opener.jpg|thumb|left|The Lions playing the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] in the field's first regular season game, on July 10, 2010]] The stadium featured a seating capacity of 27,528,{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/football/bc-lions-say-good-riddance-to-empire-field/article627204/ |title=B.C. Lions say good riddance to Empire Field |last=Sekeres |first=Matthew |date=September 11, 2011 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}} of which ca. 20,500 were bucket seats and ca. 7,000 were benches. The bucket seats were located under a roof, while there was no roof on the bench ends. In addition there are twelve [[executive boxes]], a VIP zone, [[floodlights (sport)|flood lighting]] and media facilities. Empire Field uses the FieldTurf artificial turf which was used at BC Place prior to the renovations. The venue was built so that it would not receive additional seating during playoffs. Lockers were located in construction trailers, with players having to pass through pedestrian traffic in the concourse to reach the lockers. Compared to BC Place, Empire Field's seats were located closer to the field, giving a more intimate fan experience. The use of Empire Field deteriorated the Lions' strong [[home advantage]]. As BC Place was the only domed stadium in the CFL, its pressurized air made breathing more difficult, it had high summer night temperatures and a slight air flow which put off opposing [[kicker (football)|kickers]]. The dome amplified the crowd, making team communication difficult. John Knox, president of the [[Vancouver Southsiders]], described Empire as their ancestral home and that "it gave us a taste of the experience our parents and their parents had when going to matches in Vancouver."{{cite web |url=http://metronews.ca/sports/27718/a-fond-farewell-to-empire-field/ |title=A fond farewell to Empire Field |last=Kieltyka |first=Matt |work=[[Metro International|Metro Vancouver]] |date=September 23, 2011}} [[TransLink (British Columbia)|TransLink]] served the stadium with the [[135 Express]] and Line 28. On game days, the transit operator set up special buses which connected with the [[SkyTrain (Vancouver)|SkyTrain]] at [[Renfrew Station]] and [[29th Avenue Station]]. Hastings Park is located on the [[Trans-Canada Highway]]. There are 1,300 parking spaces within a ten-minute walk from the stadium site. Several of these lots are offered with season parking tickets, which for 2010 cost $300. The stadium provided a free bicycle valet service.{{cite web |url=http://www.bclions.com/page/parking-and-transportation |title=Transit and parking information |publisher=[[BC Lions]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815121355/http://bclions.com/page/parking-and-transportation |archivedate=August 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} Compared to BC Place, which is located [[Downtown Vancouver|Downtown]], Empire Field offered poor public transport service.{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/football/cfl/bc-place-facelift/ |title=BC Place turns into state-of-the-art facility |date=September 29, 2011 |publisher=[[Sportsnet]]}} ==Events== [[File:Whitecapsgameempire.jpg|thumb|The Whitecaps during their debut game against [[Toronto FC]] on March 19, 2011]] The Lions opened the venue on June 20, 2010, with a pre-season 36–32 loss against the [[Edmonton Eskimos]], in front of a crowd of 24,763. In 2010, the team played one pre-season and nine regular-season games at the field. The team's highest attendance was the 29,517 spectators who watched the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] win 37–18 on July 10, in the first regular-season game to be played at Empire Field.{{cite web |url=http://www.bclions.com/schedule/year/2010/1 |title=2010 BC Lions Schedule |publisher=[[BC Lions]]}} The team drew an average attendance of 24,327 during the regular season, down 2,805 from [[2009 BC Lions season|2009]].{{cite web |url=http://stats.cfldb.ca/league/cfl/2010/attendance/ |title=2010 CFL Attendance |publisher=CFLDB}} During the 2011 season, the Lions played one pre-season and five regular-season games at Empire Field. For the regular season, the Lions drew an average 24,297 spectators, with a high of 25,263 seeing the [[Toronto Argonauts]] game on September 10, the last game played at Empire Field.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} This compared to an average attendance of 36,509 for the regular-season games at BC Place.{{cite web |url=http://www.bclions.com/schedule/year/2011/1 |title=2011 BC Lions Schedule |publisher=[[BC Lions]]}} The Lions' overall record at Empire Field was 5–10. The Whitecaps, who would play their [[2010 Vancouver Whitecaps FC season|2010 season]] in the [[USSF Division 2 Professional League]], remained at [[Swangard Stadium]] for that season.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/sports/Lions+Whitecaps+play+temporarily+Empire+Stadium/2368473/story.html |title=Lions, Whitecaps to play temporarily at Empire Stadium |work=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=December 21, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716084945/http://www.canada.com/sports/Lions+Whitecaps+play+temporarily+Empire+Stadium/2368473/story.html |archivedate=July 16, 2010}} The 2011 season was the franchise's debut in the MLS. The Caps' first game was a 4–2 victory over [[Toronto FC]] on March 19, in front of 22,592 spectators. The team played 13 of 17 MLS home games at Empire Field, in addition to both home games in the [[2011 Canadian Championship]] and a friendly against [[Manchester City]] as part of the [[2011 World Football Challenge]]. The Whitecaps' last game at Empire Field, a 3–1 loss to [[Seattle Sounders FC]], took place on September 24. The first match at BC Place was played on October 2. The Caps had an average attendance of 20,577 for their 13 MLS games, with the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] drawing a record high crowd of 27,500 and the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] drawing a record low crowd of 15,608. In comparison, the team's four games at BC Place drew an average 19,850 spectators. The Whitecaps' overall record for all games at Empire Field was 4–5–7{{cite web |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/schedule?month=all&year=2011&club=21&competition_type=all&broadcast_type=all&op=Search&form_id=mls_schedule_form |title=Schedule |publisher=[[Major League Soccer]]}} Braley stated that the temporary stadium cost the Whitecaps an estimated 1,600 season ticket sales and three major sponsors. The stadium hosted a concert with [[Bryan Adams]] and [[The Beach Boys]] on August 21, 2010, to celebrate the centennial anniversary of PNE.{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/music/bryan-adams-beach-boys-set-to-play-pne/article4189858/ |title=Bryan Adams, Beach Boys set to play PNE |last=Lederman |first=Marsha |date=June 22, 2010 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{BC Lions}} {{Vancouver Whitecaps}} {{Former MLS stadiums}} {{commons category|Empire Field}} [[Category:Former Major League Soccer stadiums]] [[Category:Canadian Football League venues]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Canada]] [[Category:Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] [[Category:Defunct Canadian football venues]] [[Category:BC Lions]] [[Category:Sports venues in Vancouver]] [[Category:Hastings Park]] [[Category:2010 establishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:2011 disestablishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2011]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = John Bowra | image = | country = England | fullname = John Bowra | nickname = The Kentish Shepherd | birth_date = 1716 | birth_place = [[Sevenoaks]], [[Kent]], [[England]] | death_date = {{death year and age|1785|1716|12}} | death_place = Sevenoaks, Kent, England | batting = unknown hand | bowling = underarm: unknown hand and type | role = batsman | club1 = [[London Cricket Club]] | year1 = c.1736-1756 | club2 = [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | year2 = c.1736-1756 | date = 5 September | year = 2009 | columns = 0 | source = [[H T Waghorn]] }}
'''John Bowra''' (baptised 3 June 1716 at [[Sevenoaks]], [[Kent]]; buried 22 December 1785 at Sevenoaks) was an English [[professionalism|professional]] [[cricket]]er of the mid-Georgian period who made 5 known appearances in [[first-class cricket]].
==Career== John Bowra (pronounced ''Borra'') has been identified as "Mr. Boarer", one of "three very good gamesters", who assisted [[London Cricket Club|London]] in a match on [[Kennington Common]] in 1739.<ref>Buckley, p.15</ref>
Later, in the 1740s, he appeared in several great matches on the [[Artillery Ground]] as "John Borah" and represented [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]]. He played for [[Robert Colchin]]'s XI, largely a Kent team, against [[Richard Newland (cricketer)|Richard Newland]]'s XI in 1745.<ref>Ashley-Cooper, p.36</ref>
Bowra is believed to have been a shepherd employed by [[John Frederick Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset]] to explain his title of "The Kentish Shepherd", under which he headed an eleven against "Long Tom" (i.e., [[Tom Faulkner]]) of Surrey on [[Kennington Common]] in 1747.<ref>Buckley, p.21</ref> Earlier that season, he was a member of [[Robert Colchin]]'s XI against [[William Hodsoll]]'s XI.<ref>Ashley-Cooper, p.51</ref>
Bowra's final recorded appearance was in 1749 when he again represented Colchin's XI against [[Stephen Dingate]]'s XI.<ref>Ashley-Cooper, p.53</ref>
==Family== [[William Bowra]], who played in the latter part of the 18th century, is believed to have been his son.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1731.html |title=From Lads to Lord's |accessdate=2012-10-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140105/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1731.html#bowraj |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Ashley-Cooper |first=F. S. |authorlink=F. S. Ashley-Cooper |title=At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742–1751 |year=1900 |publisher=''Cricket'' magazine}} * {{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket |year=1935 |publisher=Cotterell |isbn=}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bowra, John}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:Kent cricketers]] [[Category:1716 births]] [[Category:1785 deaths]]

{{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = white | color2 = #003cb3 | name = Kataja | nickname = | logo = Kataja Basket logo.png | imagesize = | leagues= [[Korisliiga]]
[[FIBA Europe Cup]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1949}} | history = | arena = Joensuu Areena | capacity = 2,500 | location = [[Joensuu]], [[Finland]] | colors = Blue and White
{{color box|#003cb3}} {{color box|white}} | president = | coach = | retired_numbers = '''1''' ([[Eero Oksava|11]]) | championships = '''2''' [[Korisliiga|Finnish League]]s
'''3''' [[Finnish Basketball Cup|Finnish Cups]] | website = [http://www.katajabasket.fi/edustusjoukkue/ katajabasket.fi] | h_body= 003cb3 |h_pattern_b=_basket_in_white|h_shorts= 003cb3 |h_pattern_s=_adidasonwhite | a_body= 003cb3 |a_pattern_b=_basket_with_white|a_shorts= 003cb3 |a_pattern_s=_adidaswhite }} '''Kataja Basket Club''' is a professional [[basketball]] club of sports club [[Joensuun Kataja|Kataja]] from [[Joensuu]], [[Finland]]. The team plays in the [[Korisliiga]], the highest tier of Finnish basketball. In 2015, Kataja won its first national championship, after it beat [[Bisons Loimaa]] 3–2 in the Finnish Finals. ==History== The basketball activity of the club started in 1955. In 1961, the team started playing in the Joensuu Sports Hall. The team started in provincial competitions, but quickly promoted to the national level in the 1960s. From 1976 till 1980, the team played continuously in the highest Finnish division. In the 2001–02 season, the taem won its first trophy when it won the [[Finnish Basketball Cup|Finnish Cup]]. In 2015, the first championship of Kataja was realized after a 3–2 Finals series win against [[Bisons Loimaa]]. In the 2012–13 season, Kataja started participating in European competitions when it entered the [[EuroChallenge]]. The team immediately reached the quarterfinals of the competition, and has played in Europe every season since.{{Cite web|url=http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Finland/Joensuun-Kataja-Basket/1864?Page=5|title=Kataja Basket Club History|publisher=Eurobasket.com|access-date=14 September 2016}} ==Achievements== * '''[[Korisliiga]]''' :'''Champions (2):''' [[2014–15 Korisliiga season|2014–15]], [[2016–17 Korisliiga season|2016–17]] * '''[[Finnish Basketball Cup|Finnish Cup]]''' :'''Champions (3):''' 2002, 2011, 2012 ==Players== ===Retired numbers=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan="4" style="{{Basketball color cell|Joensuun Kataja}};"|Kataja Basket Club retired numbers |- !
