/* Television */Fixed misspelling of Collinsworth
revision.text:
{{Infobox NFL single game | name = Philly Special | image = US Bank Stadium - West Facade.jpg|250 | caption = U.S. Bank Stadium, the site of the game | visitor = [[2017 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] | visitor_abbr = PHI | visitor_coach = [[Doug Pederson]] | visitor_record = 13–3 | home = [[2017 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]] | home_abbr = NE | home_coach = [[Bill Belichick]] | home_record = 13–3 | visitor_qtr1 = 9 | visitor_qtr2 = 13 | visitor_qtr3 = 7 | visitor_qtr4 = 12 | visitor_total = 41 | home_qtr1 = 3 | home_qtr2 = 9 | home_qtr3 = 14 | home_qtr4 = 7 | home_total = 33 | date = February 4, 2018 | stadium = [[U.S. Bank Stadium]] | city = [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | referee = [[Gene Steratore]] | attendance = 67,612 | odds = | network = [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]] | announcers = [[Al Michaels]], [[Cris Collinsworth]], and [[Michele Tafoya]] }} The '''Philly Special'''{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Lindsay H.|title=Nick Foles' trick-play TD catch in Super Bowl was true 'Philly Special'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/eagles/2018/02/05/nick-foles-trick-play-td-catch-super-bowl-philadelphia-eagles/306204002/|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} (also known as '''Philly Philly'''){{cite news|last=Hurley|first=Michael|title=Patriots-Eagles Mic'd Up In Super Bowl LII: Foles, Pederson Had No Fear Of Belichick's Defense|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2018/02/08/patriots-eagles-micd-up-super-bowl-lii-foles-pederson-no-fear-of-belichick-defense/|publisher=[[WBZ-TV]]|date=February 8, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} was an [[American football]] [[trick play]] between [[2017 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] players [[Corey Clement]], [[Trey Burton]] and [[Nick Foles]] on fourth-[[Down (gridiron football)|down]]-and-goal toward the end of the second quarter of [[Super Bowl LII]] on February 4, 2018. On the play, [[quarterback]] Foles moved up to behind his [[offensive line]] and the ball was directly [[Snap (gridiron football)|snapped]] to [[running back]] Clement. Clement went on to pitch the ball to Burton, who passed the ball to a wide open Foles to score a [[touchdown]]; Foles thereby became the first player in [[Super Bowl]] history to both throw and catch a touchdown.{{cite news|last=Graziano|first=Dan|title=Guts and glory: Eagles coach Doug Pederson had game for the ages|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/22326781/inside-philly-special-gutsiest-play-calling-super-bowl-history-doug-pederson-philadelphia-eagles|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} Eagles coach [[Doug Pederson]]'s decision to attempt to score a touchdown rather than attempt a [[field goal]] on the play helped put the Eagles in a better position to defeat the [[2017 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]], which they subsequently did, 41–33. The victory was the Eagles' first championship in 57 years.{{cite news|last=Manahan|first=Kevin|title=Super Bowl: Eagles vs. Patriots RECAP, score and stats|url=http://www.nj.com/sports/index.ssf/2018/02/super_bowl_2018_philadelphia_eagles_vs_new_england.html|website=[[NJ.com]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} Many analysts have since called the play one of the gutsiest play-calls in Super Bowl history.{{cite news|last=Graziano|first=Dan|title=Guts and glory: Eagles coach Doug Pederson had game for the ages |url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/22326781/inside-philly-special-gutsiest-play-calling-super-bowl-history-doug-pederson-philadelphia-eagles|website=[[ESPN]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=April 7, 2018}} It was described by [[NFL Films]] as "a play that the Eagles had never called before, run on 4th down by an undrafted rookie running back pitching the football to a third-string [[tight end]] who had never attempted an NFL pass before, throwing to a backup quarterback who had never caught an NFL (or college) pass before, [pulled off] on the biggest stage for football."[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x_RHOB9xkqo&t=6m43s Super Bowl LII Like You Have Never Seen it Before] (NFL Films, posted to YouTube on Feb 12, 2018)[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ye6dVwDb_u0&t=15m40s The "Philly Special" Stuns Belichick, Super Bowl LII] (NFL Turning Point, NFL Films, posted to YouTube on Feb 7, 2018) ==Background== A play identical to the Philly Special had been successfully run at the college level on a two-point conversion attempt in 2012 by [[Clemson Tigers football|Clemson]] with [[Andre Ellington]], [[DeAndre Hopkins]] and [[Tajh Boyd]] all involved against Georgia Tech.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bqJqaqFiwds Hopkins to Boyd 2-pt Conversion] (2012 Clemson vs Ga Tech, posted to YouTube on Mar 18, 2016) In 2016, the play was run in the NFL by the [[Chicago Bears]] against the [[Minnesota Vikings]], at [[U.S. Bank Stadium]], the same stadium in which the Philly Special also took place.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ye6dVwDb_u0&t=15m5s The "Philly Special" Stuns Belichick (Super Bowl LII) | Eagles vs. Patriots | NFL Turning Point] (NFL Films, posted to YouTube on Feb 7, 2018) Like Clemson, the Bears' attempt, led by [[Matt Barkley]], [[Jeremy Langford (American football)|Jeremy Langford]] and [[Cameron Meredith]], was a success as they scored a touchdown on the play. Eagles receiver [[Alshon Jeffery]], who was a member of the Bears at the time, stated his team's wide receivers coach [[Mike Groh]], a former Bears coach in the same position, introduced the play to Doug Pederson. Eagles offensive coordinator [[Frank Reich]] considered using it against the Vikings in the NFC Championship Game before Super Bowl LII, but relented due to the lopsided score.{{cite web|last=Emma|first=Chris|url=https://chicago.cbslocal.com/2018/02/05/philly-special-eagles-wild-trick-touchdown-was-borrowed-from-bears/|title=Philly Special, Eagles’ Wild Trick Touchdown, Was Borrowed From Bears|publisher=[[WBBM-TV]]|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=August 20, 2018}} The Patriots also pulled off a version of the Philly Special against the Eagles in 2015. [[Tom Brady]] wandered out of the pocket and the ball was snapped to [[James White (running back)|James White]]. White then pitched the ball to [[Danny Amendola]] who connected with Brady for a 36-yard pass.{{cite web|last=Toole|first=Connor|url=https://brobible.com/sports/article/patriots-philly-special-against-eagles-2015/|title=The Patriots Pulled Off Their Own Version Of ‘The Philly Special’ Against The Eagles In 2015|publisher=[[BroBible]]|date=February 2018|accessdate=September 6, 2018}} Nick Foles had played as a tight end in high school during his sophomore year. After the Super Bowl, he stated that the last time he had caught a pass for a touchdown was when he was in high school.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2X5fG1A4kuc&t=9 NFL Primetime post-game interview with Nick Foles] (ESPN, Feb 4, 2018, on YouTube) Trey Burton, at his high school, had been a first team all-state quarterback during [[Trey_Burton#Early_years|his junior and senior years]]. During [[Trey_Burton#College_career|his freshman year]] at the [[University of Florida]], he scored six touchdowns in a single game, breaking the team record set by [[Tim Tebow]].{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=302680057|title=Kentucky vs. Florida - Game Recap - September 25, 2010 - ESPN|website=ESPN.com}} Foles' experience as quarterback and tight end was at [[Westlake High School (Texas)|Westlake High]] near Austin, Texas. [[Sam Ehlinger]], who would go on to start as quarterback at the University of Texas, also played at Westlake and ran this same play during his junior year on November 28, 2015. Soon after the Super Bowl finished, Ehlinger tweeted a video of his high school touchdown catch, saying "It's a Westlake thing."{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/sehlinger3/status/960320042905808896/video/1|title=Sam Ehlinger on Twitter|website=Twitter}}[https://ftw.usatoday.com/2018/02/nfl-super-bowl-lii-patriots-eagles-trick-play-nick-foles-westlake-high-school Nick Foles' high school ran the same trick play the Eagles used in Super Bowl LII] (USA Today Sports, by Steven Ruiz, February 4, 2018 8:35 pm) ==Super Bowl LII game action prior to the play== During the second quarter, the Patriots had attempted a trick play with quarterback [[Tom Brady]] running a pattern as a receiver. The ball was thrown on target by [[Danny Amendola]], but it slipped through Brady's hands. The drive ended after the next play with the Eagles taking possession.[https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/watch-patriots-run-perfect-trick-play-in-super-bowl-but-tom-brady-gets-gator-arms/ Patriots run perfect trick play in Super Bowl but Tom Brady gets gator arms] (CBS Sports, by Will Brinson @WillBrinson, Feb 5, 2018) During Philadelphia's drive previous to their attempt at a trick play at the end of the second quarter, Nick Foles' pass was intercepted by Patriots defensive back [[Duron Harmon]].{{cite news|last=Bird|first=Hayden|title=The Patriots followed Duron Harmon’s goal-line interception with a 90-yard touchdown drive|url=https://www.boston.com/sports/new-england-patriots/2018/02/04/the-patriots-followed-duron-harmons-goal-line-interception-with-a-90-yard-touchdown-drive|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} The Patriots, led by Tom Brady, drove down the field and scored on a [[James White (running back)|James White]] 26 yard touchdown run to cut the Eagles lead to 3.{{cite news|last=Buchmasser|first=Bernd|title=Super Bowl 52 Patriots vs Eagles: James White scores New England's first touchdown of the day|url=https://www.patspulpit.com/2018/2/4/16972102/super-bowl-52-new-england-patriots-philadelphia-eagles-james-white-touchdown|website=[[SB Nation|Pats Pulpit]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Florjancic|first=Matthew|title=WATCH: James White caps 90-yard drive with touchdown run for New England Patriots|url=http://www.wkyc.com/article/sports/nfl/watch-james-white-caps-90-yard-drive-with-touchdown-run-for-new-england-patriots/95-514521279|publisher=[[WKYC|WKYC-TV]]|location=Cleveland|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} After a [[Kenjon Barner]] kick return to the 30 yard line and two plays for 7 yards, the Eagles were faced with 3rd and 3. Nick Foles was able to find Corey Clement on a wheel route for 55 yards, which set up first-and-goal, but the Eagles' drive stalled, which brought up fourth-and-goal.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Raphielle|title=Corey Clement 55-Yard Catch Puts Eagles In Red Zone|url=https://www.fanragsports.com/now/corey-clement-55-yard-catch-puts-eagles-in-red-zone/|website=FanRagSports.com|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} ==The play== [[File:Philly Special Diagram.png|thumb|300px|Shows the play's diagram|Diagram of the Philly Special]] Foles lined up in the shotgun formation, but moved up to the right side of the offensive line behind right tackle [[Lane Johnson]] and yelled "kill, kill", followed by "Lane, Lane." Foles then stayed on the right side of the offensive line and the ball was snapped to running back Corey Clement. Clement then ran left and flipped the ball to Trey Burton, to complete a reverse to the right side of the field. Finally, Burton threw the ball to Foles, who ran a route to the right corner of the end zone and made the catch for a Philadelphia touchdown. After the extra-point was successfully kicked by [[Jake Elliott]], the Eagles went up 22–12, maintaining the score into halftime. All three players who touched the ball on this play began the season as backups. Corey Clement was a third-string running back, Trey Burton was a third string tight-end and Nick Foles began the season as the backup quarterback to [[Carson Wentz]].{{cite news|last1=Belson|first1=Ken|last2=Longman|first2=Jeré|title=How Nick Foles and the Eagles Tricked the Patriots|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/05/sports/foles-super-bowl.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 6, 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Beaton|first1=Andrew|last2=Cohen|first2=Ben|title=The Trick Play the Philadelphia Eagles Borrowed to Win the Super Bowl|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-trick-play-the-philadelphia-eagles-borrowed-to-win-the-super-bowl-1517854628|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Smith|first=EJ|title=Video: Eagles' Super Bowl trick play ends with Nick Foles catching a touchdown|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/eagles/video-eagles-super-bowl-trick-play-ends-with-nick-foles-catching-a-touchdown-20180204.html|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} Many designs of this play following the Super Bowl have TE [[Zach Ertz]] blocking in a different location. ==Broadcasting calls== Before the play was called, NBC broadcaster [[Cris Collinsworth]] expressed his shock on-air that the Eagles would go for it, as he said, "This is an unbelievable call...This is like going for an onside kick. This could decide the game."{{cite news|last=Pergament|first=Alan|title=Michaels, Collinsworth have strong, perplexing moments on Super Bowl call|url=http://buffalonews.com/2018/02/04/michaels-collinsworth-have-strong-moments-on-super-bowl-call-as-well-as-perplexing-ones/|newspaper=[[The Buffalo News]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} ===Television=== [[Al Michaels]] made the call with Collinsworth for [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]]. Michaels' call: {{Cquote | quote = 4th and Goal. And they're gonna snap it and it's TREY BURTON WHO THROWS, CAUGHT FOLES, touchdown! How do you figure?}}
===Radio=== Eagles broadcasters [[Merrill Reese]] and [[Mike Quick]] made the call for [[WIP-FM|94.1 WIP]], the team's flagship station. Reese's call: {{Cquote | quote = Foles in the gun. Clement to his right. Now lines up behind Foles. Foles moves to the right and it goes directly to Clement and Clement reverses it and it goes into the end zone...AND IT'S A TOUCHDOWN BY NICK FOLES.{{cite news|last=Tornoe|first=Rob|title=Listen to Merrill Reese's call of the Eagles' Super Bowl win|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/eagles-super-bowl-2018-win-merrill-reese-call-radio-station-philadelphia-20180205.html|newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}}}}
==Controversy== Following the play, Patriots fans questioned if it was legal.{{cite web|url=https://thetylt.com/sports/super-bowl-lii-philly-speciall-illegal|title=Was the 'Philly Special' a legal play?}} According to the NFL Rulebook, the "offensive team must have at least seven players on line" and defines that a non-snapper player is on the line if the player's helmet "break[s] a vertical plane that passes through the beltline of the snapper."https://web.archive.org/web/20180313103104/https://operations.nfl.com/the-rules/2017-nfl-rulebook/ However, when looking back at the play, they argued that Eagles' wide-receiver [[Alshon Jeffery]] wasn't on the line of scrimmage, but rather slightly off it. Therefore, they argued, the Eagles had only six players on the line of scrimmage instead of the required seven. [[Fox NFL|Fox Sports]] rules expert and former NFL referee [[Mike Pereira]] even said "...They lined up wrong...Not only that, [but] it’s a trick play. And if you’re going to run a trick-type play, then you have to be lined up properly...It’s kind of one of those [penalties] that has no effect on the play. I get it. But they didn’t line up properly. And it really should’ve been called."{{cite news|last=Gallen|first=Daniel|title=Rules analyst says Philadelphia Eagles' signature 'Philly Special' in Super Bowl was illegal formation|url=http://www.pennlive.com/philadelphiaeagles/index.ssf/2018/02/rules_analyst_says_philadelphi.html|newspaper=[[The Patriot-News]]|date=February 13, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Rapaport|first=Daniel|title=Mike Pereira: Eagles lined up illegally on 'Philly Special'|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/02/12/eagles-super-bowl-trick-play-philly-special|magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=February 12, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} However, before the snap, Jeffery pointed to the down judge several times, asking if he was lined up correctly and got a head nod in return each time, indicating he was properly aligned.{{cite news|last=Kirshner|first=Alex|title=No, that Foles TD catch wasn’t from an illegal formation|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2018/2/4/16972192/nick-foles-touchdown-illegal-formation|website=SB Nation|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} This practice is typical at all levels of the sport for confirming proper alignment before a play.{{cite web |author=Zeigler, Syd |date=15 November 2016 |title=NFL illegal formation violations are increasing, and the league is cracking down |work=SB Nation |url=https://www.sbnation.com/2016/11/15/13541854/illegal-formation-referees-nfl-college |accessdate=13 July 2018}} ==Aftermath== The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since [[1960 NFL Championship Game|1960]], and first ever Super Bowl win.{{cite news|last=King|first=Peter|title=The Philly Special: Inside the ‘Set of Stones’ Play Call That Helped the Eagles Win the Super Bowl|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/02/05/super-bowl-52-eagles-patriots-peter-king-mmqb|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=February 5, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} After the game, coach Doug Pederson told reporters "We call [the play] the Philly special..." Pederson also noted that the play came from “...[looking] at different plays around the league and the collegiate ranks, and things that over the years that might fit what we do. We found this one that fit, and we’ve been working on it for the last couple of weeks and tonight was the night.”{{cite AV media|people=|date=February 4, 2018|title=Doug Pederson Post Game Press Conference, "We call it the Philly special..."|medium=YouTube|language=English|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQXWbbT5SJs|access-date=March 6, 2018|publisher=Sports Complex}} Two days after the game, Showtime's ''[[Inside the NFL]]'' released footage with audio between Coach Doug Pederson and Nick Foles. It showed Nick Foles suggesting the Philly Special, saying "You want Philly Philly?", and Pederson responding, after a thoughtful pause, by saying “Yeah, let’s do it."{{cite news|last=Knoblauch|first=Austin|title=Nick Foles ordered up 'Philly Special' trick TD play call|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000915082/article/nick-foles-ordered-up-philly-special-trick-td-play-call|publisher=National Football League|date=February 7, 2018|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}{{cite news|title=‘Philly, Philly’: ‘Inside The NFL’ Footage Reveals Nick Foles Made Trick Play Call In Super Bowl|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2018/02/06/nick-foles-trick-play-super-bowl-2018/|publisher=[[KYW-TV]]|date=February 6, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} On February 20, ESPN's [[Darren Rovell]] announced that the Philadelphia Eagles had filed for a trademark for the term "Philly Special." If the team wins the rights, they would most likely use the term for apparel and other paraphernalia. Seven other groups, including [[Yuengling]], also filed for the trademark.{{cite news|last=Chiari|first=Mike|title=Eagles File to Trademark 'Philly Special" After Super Bowl 52 Win over Patriots|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2760497-eagles-file-to-trademark-philly-special-after-super-bowl-52-win-over-patriots|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=February 20, 2018|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} Yuengling later retracted their file for the trademark. At the NFL Owners Meetings in Orlando, Doug Pederson said that the play is being unofficially retired for at least the next season due to other teams' awareness of the play.{{cite news|last=Kerr|first=Jeff|title=Doug Pederson unofficially retires 'Philly Special'|url=https://247sports.com/nfl/philadelphia-eagles/Bolt/Doug-Pederson-unofficially-retires-Philly-Special--116740051|publisher=247 Sports|date=March 27, 2018|accessdate=March 31, 2018}} On June 14, 2018, the Eagles received their Super Bowl rings. The bezel of the ring contained 127 diamonds, which is the total from the numbers of the jerseys of the three players who handled the ball after the snap on the Philly Special—Corey Clement (30), Trey Burton (88) and Nick Foles (9).{{cite news|last=West|first=Jenna|title=The Eagles' Super Bowl Rings Pay Tribute to 'Philly Special' and Dog Masks|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/06/14/eagles-super-bowl-rings-philly-special-dog-masks|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=June 14, 2018|accessdate=June 16, 2018}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r7OL5gjG_hY&t=65 The Making of the Super Bowl LII Championship Ring] (Philadelphia Eagles, posted to YouTube on Jun 15, 2018) In September 2018, a statue commemorating the Philly Special, showing the moment of discussion between Nick Foles and Doug Pederson, was unveiled at Lincoln Financial Field.{{cite news|last=Campitelli|first= Enrico|title=Bud Light unveils 'Philly Special' statue of Doug Pederson and Nick Foles |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/the700level/bud-light-unveils-philly-special-statue-doug-pederson-and-nick-foles|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]|date=September 5, 2018|accessdate=September 5, 2018}} On September 6, 2018, during the first game of the [[2018 NFL season|2018 season]], the Eagles ran a similar trick play against the [[Atlanta Falcons]] successfully, gaining a first down. Despite the Philly Special being occasionally called "Philly Philly" due to the conversation Foles and Pederson had regarding calling that play, Pederson indicated the play in the Falcons-Eagles game is called "Philly Philly." It is notable that in Super Bowl LII, the Patriots ran a play that was essentially identical, albeit not successful, to the Philly Philly play the Eagles ran against the Falcons.{{cite news|title=How the Eagles stole 'Philly Philly' from the Patriots|url=https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/video/how-eagles-stole-philly-philly-patriots|publisher=NBC Sports|accessdate=September 7, 2018}} On September 20, 2018, the [[2018 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] ran the play successfully for a two-point conversion against the [[2018 New York Jets season|New York Jets]]. RB [[Duke Johnson]] took the snap and handed the ball off to WR [[Jarvis Landry]], who threw a pass to QB [[Baker Mayfield]]. As Landry is left-handed, the play was run to the left side of the field, rather than the right side. This play has earned nicknames "Baker Special"{{cite news |title=Browns tie game on Hyde TD, Baker special |publisher=92.3 the Fan |url=https://923thefan.radio.com/articles/cleveland-browns-tie-game-carlos-hyde-td-baker-mayfield-special |date=21 September 2018}} after Mayfield, "Cleveland Special,"{{cite news |title=Watch: Browns Run 'Cleveland Special' With Baker Mayfield, Jarvis Landr |publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]] |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/09/20/baker-mayfield-browns-jets-cleveland-special-jarvis-landry |date=21 September 2018}}, and the "Dilly Special"[https://twitter.com/billbarnwell/status/1042968876693118978 The Dilly Special] in reference to [[Bud Light]]'s "Dilly Dilly" ad campaign. This play tied the game that the Browns went on to win, ending a 19-game winless streak. Bud Light placed "victory fridges" in several Cleveland-area taverns that unlocked upon the Browns winning.{{cite news |title=Browns fans open Bud Light fridges to celebrate a win with free beer |publisher=SB Nation |url=https://www.sbnation.com/2018/9/20/17883828/browns-win-free-beer-bud-light-fridges-celebrate-cleveland |date=21 September 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YDG3_ewrOWg Video of the play] (from the NFL's official YouTube channel) {{Philadelphia Eagles}} {{New England Patriots}} {{NFL on NBC}} [[Category:Philadelphia Eagles postseason]] [[Category:New England Patriots postseason]] [[Category:National Football League playoff games]] [[Category:2017 National Football League season]] [[Category:American football incidents]] [[Category:2010s in Philadelphia]] [[Category:February 2018 sports events in the United States]] [[Category:Super Bowl plays]] [[Category:Culture of Philadelphia]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Swinburne Centre | nickname = Punt Road Oval | image = [[File:Punt Road Oval.jpg|250px]] | location = Punt Rd, [[East Melbourne, Victoria]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|49|20|S|144|59|16|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1855 | opened = 1856 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City of Melbourne]] | operator = [[Richmond Football Club]] | surface = Grass | architect = | tenants = [[Richmond Football Club]] (admin + training) ([[Australian Football League|VFL/AFL]]) 1885 – present
Richmond Reserves ([[Victorian Football League|VFL]]) 2014 – present
[[Monash Tigers|Richmond Cricket Club]] 1856 – 2011
[[Melbourne Football Club]] 1942 – 1946, 1956 | construction_cost = | former_names = Richmond Cricket Ground
ME Bank Centre | seating_capacity = 6000{{cite web|title=Punt Road Oval|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=93|website=austadiums.com|publisher=Austadiums|accessdate=25 September 2015}} |}} '''Punt Road Oval''', also known by naming rights sponsorship as the '''[[Swinburne University|Swinburne]] Centre''', is an Australian rules football ground and former cricket oval located in [[Yarra Park, Melbourne|Yarra Park]], [[East Melbourne, Victoria]] situated only a few hundred metres to the east of the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG). Punt Road Oval was a former venue for the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (now Australian Football League) with 544 VFL/AFL premiership matches played there between 1908 and 1964 and as the headquarters and former home ground of the [[Richmond Football Club]]. ==History== In October 1855 an application was made for the [[Monash Tigers|Richmond Cricket Club]] to play matches on the [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]] paddock next to the site occupied by the [[Melbourne Cricket Club]]. The first documented [[cricket]] match on the oval was played on 27 December 1856. It was used as the home ground by the [[Richmond Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football Association]] (VFA) from 1885 to 1907 then in the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (VFL) from 1908 to 1964. It was also used by the [[Melbourne Football Club]] during and immediately after [[World War II]], when the MCG became a military base. Not until late 1946 were Melbourne able to play the MCG again. In [[1956 VFL season#Round 4|round 4 of the 1956 season]], Melbourne played a one off home game at Punt Road against Fitzroy, this time due to renovations at the MCG in preparation for the [[1956 Summer Olympics]]. Owing to the arrangement of the draw for 1942, [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] played one home game there against [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]] when Richmond had the bye. After the 1964 season, the capacity of the venue was to be reduced to only 22,000, after much of the outer was to be lost to the widening by 50 ft of [[Punt Road]], a notorious traffic bottleneck. Under the stewardship of President [[Ray Dunn]], Richmond negotiated to move its home games to the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] starting from 1965. The last senior [[VFL/AFL|VFL]] game was played at the venue on 22 August 1964, between [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] and [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]], where Richmond was beaten by 31 points. The club retained the venue as its training and administrative base, despite moving its home games.{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=4 November 1964|title=New den for the Tigers|page=64}} In November 1999 it hosted a [[Australian domestic limited-overs cricket tournament|Mercantile Mutual Cup]] match between Victoria and Canberra. ==Ground records - VFL== *Most Goals (Individual) in a Match: 14 by [[Doug Strang]] (Richmond vs {{AFL Nor}}, Round 2 1931) *Highest Score: 219 (Richmond 33.21 (219) def. North Ballarat 4.7 (31), Round 1 2017) *Lowest Score: 16 (Richmond 8.6 (54) def. {{AFL StK}} 1.10 (16), Round 15 1910) *Greatest Winning Margin: 188 points (Richmond 33.21 (219) def. North Ballarat 4.7 (31), Round 1 2017) *Drawn Matches: 6 *Record attendance: 46,000 (Richmond vs {{AFL Car}}, Round 9 1949) ==Today== The ground is still used for training by the [[Richmond Football Club]] and it remains the club's administrative headquarters. A statue of Tigers legend [[Jack Dyer]] is outside the ground. A $20 million redevelopment was completed in 2011. The redeveloped sports facilities at Punt Road Oval accommodate a range of business and community sports organisations, including Klim Swim, the [[VRI Fencing Club]] and the Indigenous Youth Education Centre known as the Korin Gamaji Institute. The venue remained the home ground for the [[Monash Tigers|Richmond Cricket Club]] from 1856 to the end of the 2010/11 season; in 2011/12, the club moved to [[Central Reserve]], [[Glen Waverley, Victoria|Glen Waverley]]. The naming rights for the ground were then sold to ME Bank. In 2017 it was commercially re-branded as the [[Swinburne University|Swinburne]] Centre at Punt Road Oval.{{cite news|last1=Warner|first1=Michael|title=Punt Rd Oval to be renamed Swinburne Centre as Richmond joins forces with uni|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/teams/richmond/punt-rd-oval-to-be-renamed-swinburne-centre-as-richmond-joins-forces-with-uni/news-story/ac638133fdabaa053d49da68aa76fc45?nk=b6fb24ffb8b8fd2acacae06bc9e80b29-1508750573|accessdate=23 October 2017|work=Herald Sun|publisher=News Corp Australia|date=26 May 2017}} Since being re-established in 2014, the [[Richmond Football Club#Reserves team|Richmond reserves]] team has played its [[Victorian Football League|VFL]] home games at the venue. When Richmond defeated [[Adelaide Football Club|Adelaide]] in the [[2017 AFL Grand Final|2017 Grand Final]] to win their first flag in 37 years, the venue hosted an official Richmond viewing party that attracted 15,000 people.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ByE4jIB6UlA ''Seven News Melbourne'' – September 30, 2017] YouTube (originally broadcast by Seven Network) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Punt Road Oval}} *{{Austadiums|93}} *[http://www.aroundthegrounds.bellestorie.com/punt/punt.html "Around the Grounds" - Web Documentary - Punt Road] *[http://www.richmondfc.com.au Richmond Football Club website] *[http://www.afl.com.au Australian Football League website] *[http://afltables.com/afl/crowds/vn_punt_rd.html VFL/AFL Attendance Records] *[http://www.afltables.com/afl/venues/punt_rd.html Punt Road Oval statistics] from AFL Tables {{AFL grounds}} {{Richmond Football Club}} {{Melbourne Football Club}} [[Category:Defunct Australian Football League grounds]] [[Category:Victorian Football League grounds]] [[Category:Sports venues in Melbourne]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1856]] [[Category:1856 establishments in Australia]]

revision.text:
[[File:Schoolkids doing a rugby tackle.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A young [[rugby football|rugby]] player is tackled on the shorts.]] '''Rugby shorts''' are a type of shorts that are worn while playing [[rugby football|rugby]]. They are designed to take the strains of the game and have traditionally been made from [[cotton]].
==IRB Regulations on shorts== Law 4 of the [[International Rugby Board]] (IRB) Laws of the Game of Rugby Union 2010 relates to the clothing that a player may wear while playing [[rugby union]]. In particular:
*Law 4.4 (c) states that: ''"A player must not wear any items containing buckles, clips, rings, hinges, zippers, screws, bolts or rigid material or projection."'' * Law 4.4 (f) states that: ''"A player must not wear shorts with padding sewn into them".'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irblaws.com/downloads/EN/law_4_en.pdf|title=Laws Of The Game, Law 4 Players’ Clothing|publisher=''[[International Rugby Board]]''|accessdate=2010-05-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5o4Xvoly8?url=http://www.irblaws.com/downloads/EN/law_4_en.pdf|archivedate=2010-03-08|df=}}</ref>
==Fit== Shorts should be comfortable, as tight shorts increase the chances of sustaining a serious injury. The longer and baggier shorts are, the easier it will be for opponents to pull an opponent back.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/rules_and_equipment/4204760.stm|title=Rugby union equipment: shorts|publisher=''BBC Sport''|accessdate=2010-05-27 | date=2005-09-02}}</ref> The colour and style of shorts are determined by the players club.<ref name=book>{{cite book |title= Rugby for Dummies |last1=Guthrie |first1=Patrick |last2=Brown|first2=Mathew|last3=Growden|first3=Greg|year=2007 |publisher= John Wiley & sons Canada Ltd.|isbn=9780470153277|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eO0O5zdavOkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Rugby+for+Dummies&source=bl&ots=UqzopUvfVY&sig=lLVFfHTtBCUzz5eFnCEt_ahWA3g&hl=en&ei=6xcBTMP-OMmF4QatutDLDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref>
==Construction== Rugby shorts must be able to withstand punishment and should be thick enough to provide some protection while playing. Most have pockets and many have a drawstring to prevent them coming down when tackled.<ref name=book /> While the most popular material has been cotton, modern shorts can also be made from higher grade [[polyester]] with reinforced seams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyrugby.com/news/story_9609205122.php|title=Rugby Player’s Guide|publisher=rugbyrugby.com|accessdate=2010-05-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723051219/http://www.rugbyrugby.com/news/story_9609205122.php|archivedate=2010-07-23|df=}}</ref> The use of these shorts is increasing as they are lighter, more durable, more comfortable, and better retain their color compared to traditional cotton shorts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://guide.rugbyrugby.com/Rugby%20Sections/Equipment%20Review/Performance%20Shorts.asp|title=Performance Rugby Shorts|publisher=rugbyrugby.com|accessdate=2010-05-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100403225748/http://guide.rugbyrugby.com/Rugby%20Sections/Equipment%20Review/Performance%20Shorts.asp|archivedate=2010-04-03|df=}}</ref>
===Variations===
*[[Tag rugby]] shorts are generally lighter due to the non-contact nature of the sport and have tags attached with [[velcro]] patches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrugby.ie/tagrugby/15242_about.php|title=Budlight Tag|publisher=irishrugby.ie|accessdate=2010-05-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727043516/http://www.irishrugby.ie/tagrugby/15242_about.php|archivedate=2010-07-27|df=}}</ref>
==Underwear== The use of hard plastic padding of any kind, including [[jock straps]], is forbidden in most leagues. However, in the United States, the high-padding of [[American football]] has influenced some junior leagues to allow, or in some cases require, jock straps.
==Manufacturers of rugby shorts== [[Canterbury of New Zealand]] is the most popular producer of rugby kit. [[Kooga]] are a very popular supplier, particularly to [[rugby league]] teams. Paladin Sports is also a very popular manufacturer for both Union & League, as is Triple Play from Australia.
==See also== * [[Rugby shirt]] * [[Scrum cap]] * [[Mouth guard]] * [[Rugby socks]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rCOx24TsBPI Donnacha O'Callaghan tries to play with no shorts]
{{Rugby union equipment}}
[[Category:Rugby league equipment]] [[Category:Rugby union equipment]] [[Category:Sports clothing]] [[Category:Trousers and shorts]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{More footnotes|date=July 2015}}{{Peacock|date=July 2015}}{{Weasel|date=July 2015}}}}
{{Infobox person | name = Taylor Rooks | image = | image_size = | birth_name = Taylor Lynn Rooks | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|5|22}} | birth_place = [[St Louis, Missouri]] | education = [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] | occupation = Sportscaster, Journalist | years active = 2012-present | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 9 }} '''Taylor Rooks''' (born May 22, 1992) is an American sports journalist and broadcaster. She currently appears on Bleacher Report and Turner Sports. Before joining the Turner networks, she was a host, reporter, and correspondent at SportsNet New York. Prior to the New York Market, she worked for the [[Big Ten Network]]. She appeared on BTN Live, BTN Football Pregame, and Women's Sports Report. She was a sideline reporter for CBS Sports Network for the 2016-2017 football season. Prior to SNY, CBS, and BTN, Rooks was a football and basketball recruiting reporter for scout.com. She has an on-air presence for major events, such as the Big Ten Football Championship.
==Early life and family== Taylor attended [[Peachtree Ridge High School]] in Suwanee, Georgia, United States. She graduated in 2010 as a manatee.
Rooks decided to follow in her parent's footsteps by attending the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] where she majored in broadcast journalism.<ref name="suntimes1">{{cite web|author= |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/uncategorized/7/71/215684/whats-up-with-thomas-rooks-his-run-lives-forever-in-illini-lore/ |title=WhatБ─≥s up with ... Thomas Rooks: His run lives forever in Illini lore | Chicago |publisher=Chicago.suntimes.com |date=2014-10-30 |accessdate=2015-07-25}}</ref> During her time at the University of Illinois, Rooks covered and broke national football/basketball recruiting stories while working with Scout.com. She appeared on CBS Sports Network reporting on the WBB Pre-NIT Championship at 19 years old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hawkeyesports.com/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/111612aac.html |title=Hawkeyes Set to Host Preseason WNIT Championship - Hawkeye Sports Official Athletic Site |publisher=Hawkeyesports.com |date=2010-12-02 |accessdate=2015-07-25}}</ref> Throughout college, she interned with the [[PGA Tour]], [[Comcast SportsNet Chicago]], and Fox Sports/Scout.com. She received numerous scholarships in her time in Champaign, and helped expand women's interest in broadcasting. Rooks modeled briefly, but turned her focus to sports journalism.
Rooks comes from a family of athletes. She is the daughter of Thomas Rooks, top rushing leader for the Illinois Fighting Illini; the niece of [[St. Louis Cardinals]] Hall of Famer, [[Lou Brock]]; and the niece of former Pittsburgh Steelers and New Orleans Saints NFL player, [[Marv Woodson]]. Rooks is not married and has no children.<ref name="suntimes1"/>
==Career== From August 2012 to May 2014, Taylor worked with scout.com covering Illinois football and basketball. She made national news with her stories and perspective on the game - specifically in recruiting. Rooks broke multiple stories regarding [[Cliff Alexander]], [[Jalen Brunson]], Quentin Snider, Aaron Jordan, Charles Matthews, and [[Jayson Tatum]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thesportsbank.net/illinois-illini/taylor-rooks-illini-btn/ |title=Taylor Rooks, Fox Sports Illini expert hired by BTN |publisher=Thesportsbank.net |date=2014-08-14 |accessdate=2015-07-25}}</ref>
In August 2014 -two months out of college- Taylor Rooks became an on-air host, reporter, and correspondent for the Big Ten Network.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sullivan|first1=Ryan|title=Introducing BTN Live's Newest Member Taylor Rooks|url=http://btn.com/2014/11/14/introducing-btn-lives-newest-member-taylor-rooks/|website=btn.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> She appeared nightly on the popular sports television show, BTN Live, alongside Dave Revsine, Mike Hall, and Rick Pizzo, and analysts such as Jim Jackson, [[Chuck Long]], and [[Glen Mason]]. One of her roles is to interact with fans and bring their social media topics onto the screen. Rooks regularly reports on Big Ten Games throughout the season, and travels frequently for television shows.<ref>{{cite web|title=[Look] Sideline Reporter Taylor Rooks Is Heating Up Social Right Now|url=https://www.bet.com/news/sports/2016/04/22/-look--sideline-reporter-taylor-rooks-is-heating-up-social-right.html|website=Bet.com|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> She hosts the Women's Sports Report, alongside Lisa Byington, covering all women's sports in the Big Ten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://btn.com/2014/11/14/introducing-btn-lives-newest-member-taylor-rooks/ |title=Introducing BTN Live’s Newest Member Taylor Rooks « Big Ten Network |publisher=Btn.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-25}}</ref>
In August 2016, Rooks became the newest host, reporter, and anchor for SportsNet New York. Rooks is also a sideline reporter for CBS Sports Network for the 2016-2017 college football season.
She is a well known staple on social media sites, such as Twitter and Instagram.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://rushthecourt.net/2014/10/20/big-ten-basketball-twitter-must-follows/ |title=Big Ten Basketball Twitter Must-Follows « Rush The Court |publisher=Rushthecourt.net |date=2014-10-20 |accessdate=2015-07-25}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.1070thefan.com/blogs/dan-dakich-show/audio-demand/new-star-big-ten-network 1070thefan.com] *[http://www.foxsports.com/college-football/story/ohio-state-buckeyes-cardale-jones-black-lives-matter-tweet-072315 Foxsports.com] *[http://www.bet.com/news/sports/2016/04/22/-look--sideline-reporter-taylor-rooks-is-heating-up-social-right.html] *[http://btn.com/2014/11/14/introducing-btn-lives-newest-member-taylor-rooks/]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = The Deadliest Season | image = | caption = | genre = Drama
Sport | writer = [[Ernest Kinoy]] | director = [[Robert Markowitz]] | starring = [[Michael Moriarty]]
[[Kevin Conway (actor)|Kevin Conway]]
[[Meryl Streep]] | music = [[Dick Hyman]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = [[Herbert Brodkin]] | producer = [[Robert Berger (producer)|Robert Berger]]
[[Thomas De Wolfe]] (associate producer) | editor = [[Stephen A. Rotter]] | cinematography = [[Alan Metzger]] | location = | company = Titus Productions | distributor = [[CBS]] | network = [[CBS]] | runtime = 98 minutes | first_aired = {{Start date|1977|3|16}} | website = }} '''''The Deadliest Season''''' is a 1977 American [[television film|made-for-television]] [[sports film|sports]] [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] aired on [[CBS]] on March 16, 1977. It was directed by [[Robert Markowitz]], written by [[Ernest Kilroy]] and produced by [[Titus Productions]]. The film stars [[Michael Moriarty]], [[Kevin Conway (actor)|Kevin Conway]] and [[Meryl Streep]]. ==Plot== An average professional [[ice hockey]] [[defenseman]] is relegated to the minor leagues because his play is not aggressive enough. In an effort to get back to the majors, he plays dirty and gets into fights on the ice, which gets him back to the major. His aggressive play results in the death of another player as a result of injuries sustained during a game, and results in his being charged with manslaughter. The player appears largely indifferent to the situation, appearing to view it as a normal part of playing top level ice hockey. ==Airing== ''The Deadliest Season'' was a 98-minute-long courtroom and sports drama{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/124865/The-Deadliest-Season/overview |title=The Deadliest Season |location=New York |publisher=New York Times |date=June 5, 2012 |accessdate=October 19, 2012}} made-for-TV movie that originally aired in the United States on [[CBS]] in 1977.{{cite book|title=The ultimate book of sports movies : featuring the 100 greatest sports films of all time|first1=Ray|last1=Didinger|first2=Glen|last2=Macnow|location=Philadelphia|publisher=Running Press Book Publishers|year=2009|page=316|isbn=9780762435487 |oclc=316825645}}{{cite book|author1=K. Edgington|author2=Thomas L. Erskine|author3=James Michael Welsh|title=Encyclopedia of Sports Films|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xBVtMpDYaoC&pg=PA509|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=29 December 2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-7652-1|page=509}} In Canada, the movie aired in August 1979 on CBC. In Australia, the film first aired in November 1980, and later aired on March 23, 1982 on [[ATN]]7. In 1984, it reran in New York on [[WCBS-TV|Channel 2]].{{cite book|author=New York Media, LLC|title=New York Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X-UCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA185|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=2 July 1984|publisher=New York Media, LLC|pages=185–|issn=0028-7369}} It re-ran on television in Alaska in November 1986. ==Cast== In ''The Deadliest Season'', [[Michael Moriarty]] plays the main character.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QhgyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cKQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1648,2194182&dq=the-deadliest-season+1977&hl=en|accessdate=October 19, 2012|title=Moriarty stars in hickey film|page=39|location=Montreal|newspaper=The Montreal Gazette |date=August 22, 1979}}{{cite book|author=David Quinlan|title=Quinlan's Film Stars|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KH4kmZJiUtwC&pg=PA374|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=November 2000|publisher=Batsford|isbn=978-0-7134-8651-3|page=374}} [[Gerry Miller]] and [[Kevin Conway (actor)|Kevin Conway]] also starred in this film.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41850150 |title=TUESDAY MARCH 23. |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | date=24 March 1982 |accessdate=October 19, 2012 |page=140 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vM0yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5297,831445&dq=the-deadliest-season+1977&hl=en|accessdate=October 19, 2012|location=Anchorage, Alaska|newspaper=Anchorage Daily News|date=November 16, 1986|page=102|title=Movies}} [[Sully Boyar]], [[Jill Eikenberry]], [[Walter McGinn]], [[Andrew Duggan]], [[Paul D'Amato]] and [[Mason Adams]] also appeared on ''The Deadliest Season''.{{cite news|newspaper=The Age|date=November 13, 1980|title=Wednesday TV|page=36|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ofpUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iJIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6890,6770170&dq=the-deadliest-season+1977&hl=en|location=Australia}}{{cite book|author=Douglass K. Daniel|title=Lou Grant: The Making of Tv's Top Newspaper Drama|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3vNMxIzSFnYC&pg=PA43|accessdate=19 October 2012|year=1996|publisher=Syracuse University Press|isbn=978-0-8156-0363-4|pages=43–}} Conway played the attorney who defended Mortiarty's character.{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2aojAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dSQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5676,1128195&dq=the-deadliest-season+1977&hl=en|date=March 12, 1977|title=Network Sports and Specials|page=11|newspaper=The Times-News|location=Hendersonville, North Carolina}} Adam's appearance as the team owner in the film helped land him a role in ''[[Lou Grant (TV series)|Lou Grant]].''{{Cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73893002.html?dids=73893002:73893002&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+13%2C+1989&author=Jerry+Buck&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Knight+and+Day'%3B+Mason+Adams%3A+Looking+for+Another+%60Bad-Guy'+Role&pqatl=google|title=Knight and Day'; Mason Adams: Looking for Another `Bad-Guy' Role|date= August 13, 1989|accessdate=October 19, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post |first=Jerry|last=Buck|page=y.05}} The film was written by [[Ernest Kilroy]],{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41850149 |title=MOViE GUiDE. |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | date=24 March 1982 |accessdate=19 October 2012 |page=142 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} who had already written several television dramas by that time.{{cite book|author=Alvin H. Marill|title=Sports on television|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mmoNAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=19 October 2012|year=2009|publisher=Praeger|isbn=978-0-313-35105-1}} It was directed by [[Robert Markowitz]],{{cite book|author=Jerry Roberts|title=Encyclopedia of Television Film Directors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YB6tyFdq5TcC&pg=PA366|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=15 June 2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6138-1|page=366}} and produced by [[Titus Productions]].{{cite book|author=Steven A. LuKanic|title=Film actors guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C4ZdIXclpsoC|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=January 1991|publisher=Lone Eagle|isbn=978-0-943728-38-4}} [[Meryl Streep]] made her television debut.{{cite book | title=Streep, Meryl Louise (1949-).(Narrative biography) | journal=Encyclopedia of World Biography | publication-date=1998 | publisher=Gale | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/65606216 | accessdate=19 October 2012 }}{{Citation | title=IT'S A FACT | journal=Europe Intelligence Wire | publication-date=2012-01-07 | publisher=Financial Times Ltd | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/160857758 | accessdate=19 October 2012 }} She also made her film debut role for ''[[Julia (1977 film)|Julia]]'' in the same year.{{cite book|author=Liz Sonneborn|title=A to Z of American Women in the Performing Arts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yf2741A_BkYC&pg=PA202|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=1 January 2002|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0790-5|page=202}}{{cite book|author1=Ray B. Browne|author2=Pat Browne|title=The Guide to United States Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U3rJxPYT32MC&pg=PA794|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=15 June 2001|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=978-0-87972-821-2|page=794}} Streep, playing Moriarty's wife, received fifth billing in what was her first role. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deadliest Season}} [[Category:1977 television films]] [[Category:1970s sports films]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:CBS network films]] [[Category:Ice hockey films]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Markowitz]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=May 2017}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium| stadium_name = The Pickaquoy Centre| nickname = The Picky Centre, or Picky| location = [[Kirkwall]], [[Orkney]]| opened = 1999| closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Orkney Islands Council]]| operator = The Pickaquoy Centre| construction_cost= £8.4 million| tenants = [[Orkney F.C.]]
[[Orkney official football team]] | seating_capacity = [[Concerts]]: 1,600
[[Business conference|Conferences]]: 1,600
[[Basketball]]: 1,200 }} '''The Pickaquoy Centre''' is a multi-use [[leisure centre]] in [[Kirkwall]], [[Orkney]], Scotland. It has a 1,600 seat arena with [[bleacher]] style seating, which can be condensed and used as a sports hall, with room for two five a side football pitches. The football pitches host [[Orkney F.C.]] of the [[North Caledonian Football League]] and also the [[Orkney official football team]]. It also has a 247-seat cinema, numerous meeting rooms, [[health spa]], [[gym]], indoor and outdoor children's play areas, a cafe and bar. Outside, there is an All Weather Pitch, used for football and hockey, several grass pitches used for football and rugby and an [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] track. The centre also has a campsite within its grounds. ==External links== * [http://www.pickaquoy.co.uk Official website] {{coord|58|58|59|N|2|58|18|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pickaquoy Centre}} [[Category:Football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Orkney]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1999]] [[Category:Cinemas in Scotland]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Scotland]] {{Scotland-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Torero Stadium | nickname = | image = [[Image:San diego-ca USan Diego Torero Stad09.jpg|250px|center]] | location = 5998 Alcala Park, [[San Diego, California]] 92110 | coordinates = {{coord|32.7731|-117.1837|type:landmark_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1961 | opened = 1961 | owner = [[University of San Diego]] | operator = University of San Diego | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[San Diego Toreros]] [[college soccer|soccer]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1961–present)
[[San Diego Toreros football|San Diego Toreros]] [[college football|football]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1961–present)
[[San Diego Spirit]] ([[Women's United Soccer Association|WUSA]]) (2001–2003)
[[San Diego United]] ([[National Premier Soccer League|NPSL]]) (2009)
[[San Diego Breakers]] ([[PRO Rugby|PRO]]) (2016)
[[San Diego Legion]] ([[Major League Rugby|MLR]]) (2018–present)
[[San Diego 1904 FC]] ([[United Soccer League|USL]]) (from 2019) | seating_capacity =[[Soccer]]: 6,000 | dimensions = 72 x 118 [[yards|yds]] |}} '''Torero Stadium''' is a 6,000-seat [[stadium]] in [[San Diego, California]]. It was built in 1961. It is home to the [[University of San Diego]] [[American football|football]] team, which plays in the NCAA Pioneer Football League, the [[University of San Diego]] [[soccer]] team, which plays in the NCAA West Coast Conference, the [[San Diego Legion]] team, which plays in the [[Major League Rugby]] league, and formerly the [[San Diego Breakers]], playing in the [[PRO Rugby]] competition. ==Facilities and renovations== The South stands feature approximately 1,100 bleacher seats with backs and with press box facilities. The East and North stands are all bleacher seating — the North stands hold about 3,000 fans and the stands behind the East end hold approximately 1,900. The playing surface is "Bandera" Bermuda grass, with soccer dimensions measuring 118 yards x 72 yards, with football conforming to NCAA regulations. The stadium underwent two phases of renovation to host the WUSA [[San Diego Spirit]]. Over $3.5 million was spent to enlarge the seating areas and add spectator comforts.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} In 2001, the installation of the upgraded lighting system took place, giving Torero illumination for night events. The final steps included the paving of the pedestrian walkway that curves around three-quarters of the stadium and the installation of a new sound system and a video board and scoreboard. ==Former tenants and events== Torero has hosted Major League Soccer exhibition games for the Los Angeles Galaxy and Chivas USA.[http://www.sandiego.edu/insideusd/?p=27562 "Torero Stadium Prepares for National Close-up"], November 27, 2012. The U.S. women’s national soccer team has also played friendlies at the stadium.[http://www.sandiego.edu/insideusd/?p=27562 "Torero Stadium Prepares for National Close-up"], November 27, 2012. The WUSA [[San Diego Spirit]] women's soccer team played at Torero from 2001 to 2003. Torero hosted the 2012 women's college cup soccer tournament.https://www.ncaa.com/game/soccer-women/d1/2012/12/02/north-carolina-penn-st/#autoplay=1 Since 2002, the venue has hosted [[The First 4]] men's college lacrosse invitational. The New England Patriots used the stadium as their practice facility for the week leading up to their game with the San Diego Chargers on December 7, 2014. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[Women's College Cup]] | years = 2012 | before = [[Kennesaw State University Soccer Stadium|KSU Soccer Stadium]] | after = [[WakeMed Soccer Park]] }} {{end}} {{University of San Diego}} {{San Diego Toreros football navbox}} {{San Diego Legion}} {{Pioneer Football League venue navbox}} {{California college football venues}} {{PRO Rugby}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:College soccer venues in California]] [[Category:American football venues in California]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in San Diego]] [[Category:Major League Rugby stadiums]] [[Category:San Diego Toreros football]] [[Category:Soccer venues in California]] [[Category:Sports venues in San Diego]] [[Category:Defunct National Premier Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in California]]

The '''Tournament in Łukasz Romanek Memory''' ({{lang-pl|Turniej Pamięci Łukasza Romanka}}) is an annual [[motorcycle speedway]] event held each year organized by the [[RKM Rybnik]]. The Tournament held in the Municipal Stadium in [[Rybnik]], [[Poland]]. It is named after [[Łukasz Romanek]] (1983–2006), a speedway rider who won the [[2001 Individual Speedway Junior European Championship|2001 Individual Under-19 European Champion]] and [[2003 Individual Speedway Junior Polish Championship|2003 Individual Under-21 Polish Champion]] titles. Romanek hang oneself in June 2006. == Podium == {| class="wikitable" |- align=center |width=45px {{Speedway color|4}} |'''Year''' |width=200px {{Speedway color|P1}}|'''Winner''' |width=200px {{Speedway color|P2}}|'''Runner-up''' |width=200px {{Speedway color|P3}}|'''3rd place''' |- |align=center| 2007''Świat Żużla'', No 4 (72) 2007, page 49 {{ISSN|1429-3285}}

revision.comment: /* History */
revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Yuexiushan Stadium
越秀山体育场 | image = [[File:Yuexiushan Stadium in 2017.png|225px|Yuexiushan Stadium]] | caption = Yuexiushan Stadium in 2017 | location = 4 Yingyuan Road, [[Guangzhou]], [[China]]| opened = around 1926 | owner = Guangzhou Sports Bureau| surface = Grass | tenants = [[Guangzhou R&F]] (2011-present)
[[Guangzhou Evergrande]]
(1993–1997, 2001–2010)| seating_capacity = 18,000http://www.thefootballstadiums.com/yuexiushan-stadium | |former names=the Playground for Park Of Mountain Yut Sau 粵秀山公園運動場}} The '''Yuexiushan Stadium''' ({{zh|c=越秀山体育场|s=|t=粵秀山體育場}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Guangzhou]], [[China]], named for its location at the foot of [[Yuexiu Hill]]. It is currently mostly used for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and also sometimes for athletics. It is located on 4 Yingyuan Road. The stadium, which is owned by the Guangzhou Sports Bureau, opened before 1926，and refresh in 1950 with a capacity of 35,000 people.[http://www.fussballtempel.net/afc/listeafc.html www.fussballtempel.net] However, following renovation and the installation of fixed seating in 2012, the capacity is now 18,000.{{Cite web|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2013/11/guangzhou-rf-2013-season-review-work-in-progress/|title=Guangzhou R&F 2013 Season Review: Work in progress : Wild East Football|website=wildeastfootball.net|access-date=2016-08-27}} The stadium is best reached by taking [[Guangzhou Metro]] [[Line 2, Guangzhou Metro|Line 2]] to [[Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall Station (Guangzhou)|Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall Station]]. == History == [[File:1930越秀山體育場.jpg|thumb|left|Yut Sau Shan Public Stadium in early 1930s.]] [[File:Yuexiushan Stadium.jpg|thumb|upright|Yuexiushan Stadium in 2009, preparing for [[2010 Asian Games]].]] In the past [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] the place was occupted by the ammunition depot.When the [[Republic China|Republic]] era came, [[Chen Jiongming|Chen Chiung-ming]] had designed the place to be used for sports. As the playground opened before 1926, it had muddy ground and few facilities. In 1950 the new government refresh the playground as both a sports stadium and arena for civic celebrations. As the home stadium of first the Guangzhou city side and later the Guangdong provincial side, Yuexiushan hosted a large number of friendly matches with international opposition in the late 1950s and early 1960s including against Algeria, Sweden and Soviet champions Spartak Moscow.{{Cite news|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2016/09/yuexiushan-the-cradle-of-cantonese-football-part-one/|title=Yuexiushan: The cradle of Cantonese football, part one|date=2016-09-13|newspaper=Wild East Football|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-12}} These games would come to be known as 'foreign battles' and would see both Cuba and Albania play at Yuexiushan in the early 1970s and, after the end of Cultural Revolution, visiting sides included the West German Olympic Team.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gzrffc.com.cn/index.php?m=Article&a=show&id=880|title=越秀山情结--65年回首英雄地，为什么这里是南粤足球的圣地？-越秀山情怀故事|last=品拓互联-www.dotodo.net|website=www.gzrffc.com.cn|access-date=2016-11-12}} Yuexiushan was also the venue for Guangzhou's [[National Day of the Republic of China|National Day]] celebrations, although an event to mark the 40th anniversary of the Russian October Revolution ended in disaster when 33 people were killed in a crush. The Yuexiushan Stadium hosted the inaugural [[Guangdong–Hong Kong Cup|Guangdong-Hong Kong Cup]] match in early 1979, which Guangdong won 1-0. By the late 1980s Yuexiushan was no longer the premier ground in Guangzhou with the opening of the new [[Tianhe Stadium|Tianhe stadium]]. However, Guangzhou continued to play their regular fixtures at Yuexiushan and finished second in the National Championship in 1992 and 1994, helped by an unbeaten record of 21 games at Yuexiushan.{{Cite news|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2016/11/yuexiushan-the-cradle-of-cantonese-football-part-two/|title=Yuexiushan: The cradle of Cantonese football, part two|date=2016-11-08|newspaper=Wild East Football|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-12}} Yuexiushan has undergone multiple renovations since the late 1990s which have seen player facilities in the entrance tower at the city end of the ground improved and a roof, electronic scoreboard and fixed plastic seating installed for spectators. Fans sitting at the Yuexiu Park end of the ground are still exposed to the elements though. Following their promotion to the [[Chinese Super League]] (CSL), original tenants Guangzhou Evergrande (the successors to the Guangzhou side founded in 1954 and the first Chinese sports club with 5 million followers on Weibohttp://en.ytsports.cn/news-963.html) moved out of the Yuexiushan Stadium and across town to Tianhe Stadium for the 2011 season.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gzevergrandefc.com/english/about.aspx?target=text&ftid=297|title=Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao Club History|last=|first=|date=|website=www.gzevergrandefc.com/|publisher=|access-date=12 November 2016}} Guangzhou R&F played their first home game at Yuexiushan in the summer of 2011 and were promoted to the CSL at the end of the season. Following R&F's third-place finish in 2014, Yuexiushan hosted four Asian Champions League games under floodlights in 2015. Yuexiushan was renovated over the winter of 2016/17. The pitch was relayed, VIP facilities improved and the whole stadium painted blue (the colour of tenants Guangzhou R&F).{{Cite web|url=http://www.gzrffc.com.cn/index.php?m=Article&a=show&id=1909|title=富力TV {{!}} 越秀山回归倒计时，精彩揭秘抢先看-富力TV报道|last=品拓互联-www.dotodo.net|website=www.gzrffc.com.cn|access-date=2017-05-01}} The first match at the refurbished stadium was held on 28 April 2017 when R&F were defeated 1-3 by Guizhou Hengfeng in the CSL.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gzrffc.com.cn/index.php?m=Article&a=show&id=1911|title=遭遇赛季首败，回归越秀山我们重新出发-赛事新闻|last=品拓互联-www.dotodo.net|website=www.gzrffc.com.cn|access-date=2017-05-01}} Yuexiushan was later repainted in gold and green after Guangzhou R&F suffered a poor run of form. The decision was reportedly made on feng shui principles.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestadiumbusiness.com/2017/08/11/csl-team-superstitiously-paints-entire-stadium-gold-climbs-third-league/|title=CSL team superstitiously paints entire stadium gold, climbs to third in league - The Stadium Business|website=www.thestadiumbusiness.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-12-31}} ==Notable events== *October 1976: Guangdong 0 - 2 Australia. Australia were the first international side to tour China after Chairman Mao's death.{{Cite web|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2017/12/enlightening-say-least-australias-1976-tour-china/|title=“Enlightening to say the least” – Australia’s 1976 tour of China - Wild East Football|website=wildeastfootball.net|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-12-31}} *May 1978: Yuexiushan hosts Guangdong v [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] friendly match{{Cite web|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2017/01/football-diplomacy-west-broms-1978-tour-of-china/|title=A trumpet-playing panda and half-time ice cream: West Brom’s 1978 tour of China - Wild East Football|website=wildeastfootball.net|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-05-01}} *December 25, 2010: ''[[Super Show 3 Tour|3rd Asia Tour: Super Show 3]]'' - The Boy band South Korean [[Super Junior]] held a concert to a sold-out crowd of 30,000 people at the stadium. *March 17, 2012: Yuexiushan hosts the first Canton Derby as Guangzhou R&F beat reigning league champions and former Yuexiushan tenants Guangzhou Evergrande 2-0.{{Cite web|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2012/03/guangzhou-fuli-2-0-guangzhou-evergrande-canton-derby-shock/|title=Guangzhou Fuli 2 – 0 Guangzhou Evergrande: Canton Derby Shock : Wild East Football|website=wildeastfootball.net|access-date=2016-08-27}} *Spring 2015: Yuexiushan hosts [[Asian Champions League]] football as Guangzhou R&F play in the group stages. R&F came through two qualifying rounds after finishing third in the Chinese Super League in 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://wildeastfootball.net/2014/10/yuexiushan-news-asia-here-we-come/|title=Yuexiushan News: Asia here we come! : Wild East Football|website=wildeastfootball.net|access-date=2016-08-27}} ==See also== * [[Sports in China]] * [[Yuexiu Hill]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Guangzhou F.C.}} {{Guangzhou R&F F.C.}} {{Guangzhou}} {{coord|23.139216|113.260739|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} [[Category:Sports venues in Guangzhou]] [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Yuexiu District]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.]] [[Category:Guangzhou R&F F.C.]] [[Category:Venues of the 2010 Asian Games]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1950]]
